Savannah, Alice, Lewis and Vanessa flashback on how they became a part of the Hellcats which ultimately makes Marti realize that she can't make a decision on her own. Travis is beaten by two men in prison on Bill Marsh's appeal so he fires his lawyers "Marti, Morgan and Julian". When Marti receives news of what happened to Travis she and Savannah come clean to the squad and ask for support, which they ultimately get including Alice. |LineColor = 0033CC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 15 |Title = God Must Have My Fortune Laid Away |DirectedBy = John Behring |WrittenBy = Vince Gonzales & Matthew B. Roberts |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2011|2|15}} |ProdCode = 2J5565 |Aux4 = 1.58{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/02/16/tuesday-final-ratings-ncis-traffic-light-adjusted-down/82898|title=Tuesday Final Ratings: 'NCIS,' 'Traffic Light' Adjusted Down|last=Gorman|first=Bill|work=TV by the Numbers|date=February 16, 2011|accessdate=February 16, 2011}} |ShortSummary = The Hellcats decide to throw a [[toga party]] as a last farewell. Meanwhile, Marti, Vanessa, Julian, and Red hatch a plan to take down Bill Marsh once and for all. Step 1 of the plan was for Red to have Bill say something threatening and betraying about Jake, which they recorded. Step 2 they ask that Jake confess to robbing the pharmacy so Travis can be set free but Jake refused and shut them down. They showed Jake the recording of Bill Marsh, but he stormed out angry. Hopeless, Marti goes to see Travis one more time where she tells him that Jake refused to confess so they are going to take this to the media. She tells him about their situation and Travis tries to stop Marti from letting down the Hellcats but Marti is still determined to set Travis free. On the other hand, Alice and Savannah invite firemen to their party. In the party Savannah seems to be getting along with the fireman Keith. After Marti comes to the party Alice questions her about Jake and finds him on the football field. Jake resists but Alice finally convinces him to confess and prays with him; regardless of her disbelief in God. Finally, Jake calls a press conference and confesses but to his surprise, everyone is proud of him and considers him a hero. Red, Julian and Marti blackmail Bill Marsh with his recording so he will retire without pension and he accepts. As Travis is leaving jail he makes eye contact with Jake while Jake is entering the jail. After Jake gets to his cell, Jake starts to cry. In the last scene we see the Hellcats singing "[[Redemption Song]]" in Cheertown with Travis, Marti's mom, Vanessa, Julian, Lewis, Savannah's sister and Morgan. |LineColor = 0033CC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 16 |Title = Fancy Dan |DirectedBy = John Dahl |WrittenBy = Anne Kenney |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2011|2|22}} |ProdCode = 2J5566 |Aux4 = 1.64{{cite web|last=Seidman|first=Robert|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/02/24/tuesday-final-ratings-glee-adjusted-up-ties-ncis-the-good-wife-adjusted-up-raising-hope-traffic-light-adjusted-down/83561|title=Tuesday Final Ratings: 'Glee' Adjusted Up, Ties 'NCIS'; 'The Good Wife' Adjusted Up; 'Raising Hope,' 'Traffic Light' Adjusted Down|work=TV by the Numbers|date=February 24, 2011|accessdate=February 24, 2011}} |ShortSummary = Dan comes back for his brother's wedding, where Marti and Savannah both compete for the affections of Dan. While at the wedding, Marti performs, and she and Savannah both dress up in hope of winning Dan, however they later find out that Dan has a girlfriend whom he kisses in front of Savannah and Marti. Alice feels guilty about convincing Jake to confess and refuses to visit him in jail. However, a talk with Travis convinces her to go to him. Dan's father reminds him that Marti is not a good match for him as they are both "trainwrecks" but Savannah encourages Dan to be a better person and more mature. Marti and Dan agreeing to just stay friends and Dan reunites with Savannah after he asks for her forgiveness. Derrick is getting shipped out for a year with the army and asks Vanessa to marry him before he leaves. She initially agrees but at the last second cannot sign the marriage certificate. Derrick guesses that it's because of Red and breaks up with Vanessa, wishing her well for her future with Red. The episode ends with a kiss between Dan and Savannah. |LineColor = 0033CC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 17 |Title = Don't Make Promises (You Can't Keep) |DirectedBy = [[Robert Berlinger]] |WrittenBy = Amanda Alpert Muscat |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2011|3|1}} |ProdCode = 2J5567 |Aux4 = 1.46{{cite web|last=Gorman|first=Bill|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/03/02/tuesday-final-ratings-american-idol-adjusted-up-raising-hope-one-tree-hill-adjusted-down/84377|title=Tuesday Final Ratings: 'American Idol' Adjusted Up; 'Raising Hope,' 'One Tree Hill' Adjusted Down|work=TV by the Numbers|date=March 2, 2011|accessdate=March 2, 2011}} |ShortSummary = The Hellcats and Cyclones have a crisis when Alice discovers they have the same song for nationals, which causes problems. They compete by doing a routine in front of the band, which gave both teams permission to use the song, where the best routine claims the song for nationals. The band turns out to be lazy and rude drunks who pick the Hellcats due to their skimpier uniform. The Hellcats reject the song and the band, followed suit by the Cyclones. Savannah finds out the father of Charlotte's baby is her ex-boyfriend, Noah. Charlotte announces wedding plans with the baby's father, but an interrogation from Savannah forces Noah to admit that he has no feelings for Charlotte. Savannah tries to tell Charlotte that marrying Noah is a mistake because he doesn't love her, but she refuses to see sense. Eventually Charlotte realises that things won't work, and calls off the engagement. Travis slips about Marti's father with a song that Marti's father wrote, causing Marti to regain interest and confronting Wanda to find out more about him. Wanda continues to deny Marti information about her father, stating that he was simply a bad man. Marti doesn't accept this, and goes through her father's things in the hopes of getting to know him better. |LineColor = 0033CC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 18 |Title = Woke Up Dead |DirectedBy = [[Andy Fickman]] |WrittenBy = Jennifer Schuur |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2011|4|19}} |ProdCode = 2J5568 |Aux4 = 1.19{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/04/20/tuesday-final-ratings-glee-dwts-results-ncis-la-10p-repeat-adjusted-up-raising-hope-traffic-light-adjusted-down/90135|title=Tuesday Final Ratings: 'Glee,' DWTS Results, NCIS: LA 10p Repeat Adjusted Up; 'Raising Hope,' 'Traffic Light' Adjusted Down|last=Seidman|first=Robert|work=TV by the Numbers|date=April 20, 2011|accessdate=April 20, 2011}} |ShortSummary = The Hellcats help Dan with his short movie trailer, involving zombies. Marti continues to investigate into her father's past with help from Deirdre ([[AJ Michalka]]), a music store employee. Kelsey, a magazine reporter (who previously wrote a story on the Hellcats) convinces Alice to work with her in exposing athletes cheating on their assignments, with Lewis being one those athletes. |LineColor = 0033CC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 19 |Title = Before I Was Caught |DirectedBy = Andy Wolk |WrittenBy = Peter Calloway |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2011|4|26}} |ProdCode = 2J5569 |Aux4 = 0.98{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/04/27/tuesday-final-ratings-dancing-with-the-stars-adjusted-up-body-of-proof-raising-hope-biggest-loser-adjusted-down/90802|title=Tuesday Final Ratings: 'Dancing With The Stars' Adjusted Up; 'Body Of Proof,' 'Raising Hope,' 'Biggest Loser' Adjusted Down|last=Gorman|first=Bill|work=TV by the Numbers|date=April 27, 2011|accessdate=April 27, 2011}} |ShortSummary = Marti is about to represent Lewis in the case concerning the cheating scandal, when it's discovered that he's actually covering up for Savannah. As Marti is working on the case, it becomes too personal for her and Julian. She feels a hint of jealousy after seeing all the couples together after she wins the cheating case and then goes to visit Julian in his 3-Strikes office, the episode ending in them both kissing. |LineColor = 0033CC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 20 |Title = Warped Sister |DirectedBy = [[Tricia Brock (director)|Tricia Brock]] |WrittenBy = James Eagan |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2011|5|3}} |ProdCode = 2J5570 |Aux4 = 1.01{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/05/04/tuesday-final-ratings-the-voice-ncis-dancing-with-the-stars-the-biggest-loser-adjusted-up-raising-hope-traffic-light-adjusted-down/91583|title=Tuesday Final Ratings: 'The Voice,' 'NCIS,' 'Dancing With The Stars,' 'Glee,' 'The Biggest Loser,' 'Hellcats' Adjusted Up; 'Raising Hope,' 'Traffic Light' Adjusted Down|last=Seidman|first=Robert|work=TV by the Numbers|date=May 3, 2011|accessdate=May 3, 2011}} |ShortSummary = Marti discovers more about her father, Rex, with Julian's help; she discovers that Deirdre is her half-sister, and their bond grows after a rocky start. Savannah loses her scholarship after her passing grade from a class is revoked because of her cheating, forcing her to ask her father for help with tuition money. Later, police arrest Savannah's dad on account of firewire and fraud, using the excuse of him writing a big check to Savannah. At Charlotte's baby shower, Lewis discovers the reason behind Savannah and Kathy's bitterness towards each other. Vanessa and Red continue to feel tension from Emily ([[Camille Sullivan]]), Red's ex-wife who is investigating the Lancer athletic department. The episode ends with Marti and Julian kissing again. |LineColor = 0033CC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 21 |Title = Land of 1,000 Dances |DirectedBy = Debbie Allen |WrittenBy = Curtis Kheel |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2011|5|10}} |ProdCode = 2J5571 |Aux4 = 1.18{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/05/11/tuesday-final-ratings-the-voice-glee-dancing-adjusted-up-raising-hope-traffic-light-adjusted-down/92264/|title=Tuesday Final Ratings: 'The Voice,' 'Glee,' 'Dancing' Adjusted Up; 'Raising Hope,' 'Traffic Light' Adjusted Down|last=Gorman|first=Bill|work=TV by the Numbers|date=May 11, 2011|accessdate=May 11, 2011}} |ShortSummary = Marti is shocked to find out that Julian has a daughter and is finalizing a divorce with his soon-to-be ex-wife, and she asks him to help out Savannah's father in prison. Lewis and Kathy enter a dance competition to win a [[Toyota]] [[Toyota RAV4|Rav-4]] for Lewis's father, but Alice and Morgan enter too. Kathy's knee injury forces Alice and Lewis to partner up despite Alice's injured feet. Mr. Monroe is bailed out of prison but later goes on the run, apologizing to Savannah over the phone for disappointing her. |LineColor = 0033CC }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber = 22 |Title = I'm Sick Y'all |DirectedBy = Omar Madha |WrittenBy = Kevin Murphy |OriginalAirDate = {{Start date|2011|5|17}} |ProdCode = 2J5572 |Aux4 = 1.16{{cite web|url=http://www.thetvaddict.com/2011/05/18/tv-ratings-tuesday-may-17-2011/|title=TV Ratings: Tuesday May 17, 2011|last=|first=|work=The TV Addict|date=May 17, 2011|accessdate=May 18, 2011}} |ShortSummary = Strep throat hits Lancer, and the Hellcats find themselves a few members short as they prepare for Nationals, leaving the squad disqualified from competing. Charlotte goes into labor a month early and Savannah ditches Nationals to be at her sister's side. Marti and Deidre hit some major road bumps in their relationship, due to Deidre refusing to acclimate to Marti's cheerleading life. The sisters later patch things up until Marti learns that Deidre has been in contact with their father meaning that Deidre was lying to Marti from the moment they met. |LineColor = 0033CC }} |} == Reception == [[File:Alyson Michalka.jpg|thumb|upright|right|''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' and ''[[Newsday]]'' praised Michalka by saying she has a big talent. ''[[The New York Times]]'' and ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' criticized her performance.]] ===Critical reception=== The show has received mixed reviews, with [[Metacritic]] giving it a score of 51 percent, based on reviews from 22 critics.{{Cite news|title=Critic Reviews for Hellcats Season 1 at Metacritic |publisher= [[CBS]] | work = [[Metacritic]] |url= http://www.metacritic.com/tv/hellcats/season-1/critic-reviews |accessdate= September 5, 2010}} It was praised and criticized by critics in several round-up reviews of [[2010 in television]]. ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' had a good first impression of the pilot episode, saying ''Hellcats'' has a predictable story but, on the other hand, Michalka and Tisdale seem perfect for their roles. The newspaper also wrote the cheerleading world portrayed in the series is a "fun and deep world to explore".{{Cite news|title=Pilot View: The CW's new drama 'Hellcats{{'-}} |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=July 1, 2010|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/showtracker/2010/07/pilot-view-the-cws-new-drama-hellcats.html |last=Elena Fernandez|first=Maria|accessdate=August 26, 2010}} The journal later gave a complete review of the series, comparing it to 1983's film ''[[Flashdance]]'' aimed squarely at audiences too young for ''[[Gossip Girl]]'' but too old for ''[[Hannah Montana]]''.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/sep/08/entertainment/la-et-hellcatsnikita-20100908|title=Television Review: 'Hellcats' and 'Nikita' on the CW|last=McNamara|first=Mary|date=September 8, 2010|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=January 3, 2010}} Verne Gay of ''[[Newsday]]'' praised Michalka's performance in the series,{{Cite news|title=Three cheers for kids of 'Hellcats{{'-}}|work=[[Newsday]]|date=September 7, 2010|url=http://www.newsday.com/entertainment/tv/three-cheers-for-kids-of-hellcats-1.2257575|last=Gay|first=Verne|accessdate=September 8, 2010}} while ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' praised the series itself and said it has "multilayered characters that defy expectations".{{Cite news|title=Hellcats -- TV Review|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|date=September 8, 2010|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/review/hellcats-tv-review-29949|last=Dawn|first=Randee|accessdate=September 8, 2010}} Mara Reinstein of ''[[Us Weekly]]'' gave an early review of the first episode of the series, saying ''Hellcats'' has "plenty of winning elements" but added that the series lacks spirit. She also praised the performance and Marti's relationship with her mother.{{Cite news|title=News - Review Hellcats|work=[[Us Weekly]]|date=August 24, 2010|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/moviestvmusic/news/review--hellcats-2010248 |last=Reinstein|first=Mara|accessdate=August 26, 2010}} [[ABC News]] listed ''Hellcats'' as one of the ten best new shows of 2010's fall season and described the series as "almost laughably formulaic" and added it "works like a charm".{{Cite news|title=Among Fall's TV Frosh, 10 New Shows Worth Sampling|publisher=[[ABC News]]|date=September 1, 2010|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/wireStory?id=11531852 |last=Moore|first=Frazie|accessdate=September 1, 2010}} Brian Lowry of ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' praised the series' promise, and said that the series has a ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]''-like element in the script, while also criticizing Michalka and acclaiming O'Grady's performance. Lowry also added ''Hellcats''{{'s}} premiere "isn't quite unabashedly trashy enough to completely qualify as a guilty pleasure".{{Cite news |title= Hellcats Review - TV Shows Reviews |work= [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date= September 5, 2010 |url= http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117943422.html |last= Lowry |first= Brian |accessdate= October 9, 2010}} Curt Wagner of ''[[ChicagoNow]]'' said the series is predictable and has unrealistic situations, and criticized the lack of fun in the jokes. The journal also praised Tisdale's performance, claiming she was the one who made him laugh the most.{{Cite news|title=Review: CW cheerleader dramedy 'Hellcats' fails to 'Bring It On{{'-}}|work=[[ChicagoNow]]|date=September 8, 2010|url=http://www.chicagonow.com/blogs/show-patrol/2010/09/review-cw-cheerleader-dramedy-hellcats-fails-to-bring-it-on.html|last=Wagner|first=Curt|accessdate=September 8, 2010}} Alessandra Stanley of ''[[The New York Times]]'' criticized Michalka's performance and called the series a "soft-porn music video for teenagers".{{Cite news|title=Lethal Woman With Weapons Is Out for Covert Vengeance|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 7, 2010|url= http://tv.nytimes.com/2010/09/08/arts/television/08nikita.html?_r=1&pagewanted=2|last=Stanley|first=Alessandra|accessdate=September 8, 2010}} ''[[Washington Post]]'''s Hank Stuever was critical about the pilot episode, describing it as "mean-spirited, painfully dumb and badly acted". He also wrote ''Hellcats'' is the opposite to [[Fox Broadcasting Company|Fox]]'s ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]''.{{Cite news|title=New CW shows 'Nikita' and 'Hellcats' cutthroat without the edge|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=September 8, 2010|url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/09/07/AR2010090706059.html|last=Stuever|first=Hank|accessdate=September 8, 2010}} ===Ratings=== The pilot episode "[[A World Full of Strangers]]" averaged a total of 3.0 million viewers and scored a 2.0 rating in the network's target audience of women 18–34, which marks the first premiere to ever match or build on an ''[[America's Next Top Model]]'' lead-in since The CW began. ''Hellcats'' also delivered the largest non-''Top Model'' performance in The CW's Wednesday 9–10 pm time period in 3 years since the ''[[Gossip Girl (TV series)|Gossip Girl]]'' series premiere.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2010/09/09/rah-rah-sis-boom-bah-hellcats-scores-a-ratings-first-evah/62740 |title=Rah-Rah-Sis-Boom-Bah! 'Hellcats' Scores a Ratings First Evah! |date=September 9, 2010 |last=Seidman |first=Robert |work=TV by the Numbers |accessdate=September 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100912132730/http://tvbythenumbers.com/2010/09/09/rah-rah-sis-boom-bah-hellcats-scores-a-ratings-first-evah/62740 |archivedate=September 12, 2010 |df= }} On September 10, the network aired an encore of the pilot episode which averaged a total of 2.42 million viewers and won the hour with adults 18–49.{{Cite news|title=TV Ratings: 'Stand Up To Cancer' Draws 10.6 Million on Broadcast; Rerun of CW's 'Hellcats' Wins 8pm With 18-49 |work=TV by the Numbers |url=http://tvbythenumbers.com/2010/09/11/tv-ratings-stand-up-to-cancer-averages-10-6-million-on-broadcast-nets-rerun-of-cws-hellcats-wins-8pm-hour-with-18-49/62923 |date=September 11, 2010 |last=Seidman |first=Robert |accessdate=September 11, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100913214509/http://tvbythenumbers.com/2010/09/11/tv-ratings-stand-up-to-cancer-averages-10-6-million-on-broadcast-nets-rerun-of-cws-hellcats-wins-8pm-hour-with-18-49/62923 |archivedate=September 13, 2010 |df= }} ''Hellcats'' delivered The CW's most watched Tuesday of the season with 2.2 million viewers watching "Papa, Oh Papa", its 12th episode and the first in its new Tuesday 9–10 pm timeslot.{{Cite news|title=New Pairing of 'One Tree Hill' and 'Hellcats' Delivers The CW's Most Watched Tuesday of the Season|work=The CW Television Network|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/01/26/new-pairing-of-one-tree-hill-and-hellcats-delivers-the-cws-most-watched-tuesday-of-the-season/80334|date=January 26, 2011|publisher=TV by the Numbers|accessdate=January 26, 2011}} Ratings fell rapidly as the series progressed, with the nineteenth episode, "Before I Was Caught", hitting a series low, with less than a million viewers watching it on April 27, 2011.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/04/27/tuesday-final-ratings-dancing-with-the-stars-adjusted-up-body-of-proof-raising-hope-biggest-loser-adjusted-down/90802|title=Tuesday Final Ratings: 'Dancing With The Stars' Adjusted Up; 'Body Of Proof', 'Raising Hope', 'Biggest Loser' Adjusted Down|last=Gorman|first=Bill|work=TV by the Numbers|date=April 27, 2011|accessdate=April 27, 2011}} The finale was watched by 1.16 million viewers. The series averaged 2.11 million viewers with live +7 day DVR viewing.{{cite web|url=http://tvbythenumbers.zap2it.com/2011/06/13/modern-family-tops-dvr-ratings-gain-for-the-2010-11-season-fringe-has-biggest-increase-by-dvr/95418/|title='Modern Family' Tops DVR Ratings Gain For The 2010–11 Season; 'Fringe' Has Biggest % Increase By DVR|last=Gorman|first=Bill|date=June 13, 2011|work=TV by the Numbers|accessdate=June 20, 2011}} ===Awards and nominations=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year !! Award !! Category !! Result !! Notes |- |rowspan="2"| 2011 | [[People's Choice Awards]] | Favorite New TV Drama{{cite web|title=Display nominees/winners for the year: 2011 |url=http://www.peopleschoice.com/pca/awards/nominees/index.jsp?year=2011 |accessdate=January 14, 2012 |year=2011 |publisher=[[People's Choice Awards]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715063438/http://www.peopleschoice.com/pca/awards/nominees/index.jsp?year=2011 |archivedate=July 15, 2011 |df= }} |{{nom}} | |- | [[Motion Picture Sound Editors|Golden Reel Awards]] | Best Sound Editing: Short Form Musical in Television{{cite web|title=2011 Golden Reel Award Nominees: Television|url=http://www.mpse.org/goldenreels/2011awards/2011tvnominees.html|accessdate=August 10, 2011|year=2011|publisher=[[Motion Picture Sound Editors]]}} |{{nom}} |"Back of a Car" |} ==Broadcast== While presenting its 2010–11 season schedule on May 21, 2010, [[The CW]] announced its intention to air ''Hellcats'' in the United States after ''America's Next Top Model'' on Wednesday nights starting September 8, 2010, at 9 pm. The series moved to Tuesday nights in the 9–10 pm timeslot, starting with the twelfth episode. ''Hellcats'' has been syndicated for broadcast in several countries worldwide, including Australia,{{Cite news|title=Love cheerleading? |work=[[Go! (Australian TV channel)|Go! Channel]] |publisher=[[MSN]] |date=August 12, 2010 |url=http://go.ninemsn.com.au/blog.aspx?blogentryid=685276&showcomments=true |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100821122504/http://go.ninemsn.com.au/blog.aspx?blogentryid=685276&showcomments=true |dead-url=yes |archive-date=August 21, 2010 |accessdate=August 26, 2010 }}{{cite web|publisher=[[TV Tonight]]|first=David|last=Knox|title=Programming Archive:|url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/tag/hellcats|date=February 16, 2011|accessdate=February 17, 2011}} Canada,{{Cite news|title=/A\: ''Hellcats'' |url=http://www.atv.ca/home/tvshows_hellcats.aspx |accessdate=August 10, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100823204749/http://www.atv.ca/home/tvshows_hellcats.aspx |archivedate=August 23, 2010 |df= }} [[Greece]],{{cite web |url=http://www.star.gr/tv/seires/1068/HELLCATS_ |title=Αναζήτηση στις Σειρές |publisher=Star.gr |date= |accessdate=2012-06-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120603222049/http://www.star.gr/tv/seires/1068/HELLCATS_# |archive-date=2012-06-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }} Ireland,{{cite web|title=Hellcats|url=http://www.tvguideireland.com/titlesearch.asp?title=Hellcats|work=[[TV Now]]|accessdate=May 13, 2011}}{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[Israel]],{{cite web|url=http://www.hot.net.il/heb/TV/channels/hotchannels/hot3/hellcats/ |script-title=he:הלקאטס |trans-title=Hellcats |publisher=[[HOT (Israel)|HOT]] |language=Hebrew |accessdate=March 2, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120714053002/http://www.hot.net.il/heb/TV/channels/hotchannels/hot3/hellcats/ |archivedate=July 14, 2012 |df= }} United Kingdom,{{Cite news|title=MTV picks up 'Hellcats' for the UK|work=[[Digital Spy]]|date=November 25, 2010|url=http://www.digitalspy.co.uk/ustv/news/a289911/mtv-picks-up-hellcats-for-the-uk.html |accessdate=November 26, 2010}} [[Brazil]],{{Cite news|title=As Estréias de 2011 dos Canais Turner no Brasil|work=[[Veja (magazine)|Veja]]|date=November 26, 2010|url=http://veja.abril.com.br/blog/temporadas/series-anos-2000-2009/as-estreias-de-2011-dos-canais-turner-no-brasil/ |language=Portuguese|accessdate=November 26, 2010}} Spain,{{Cite news|title=Hellcats se preestrena en Cosmopolitan TV|work=Dentrotele|date=December 30, 2010|url=http://www.dentrotele.com/2010/12/30/hellcats-se-preestrena-en-cosmopolitan-tv/ |language=Spanish|accessdate=December 30, 2010}} the [[Arab world|Arab World]],{{Cite news|title={{-'}}Hellcats' official MBC4 website |url=http://www.mbc.net/hellcats/ |accessdate=February 8, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110121102042/http://www.mbc.net/hellcats/ |archivedate=January 21, 2011 |df= }} [[Latin-America]],{{Cite news|title={{-'}}Hellcats' official Boomerang website |url=http://la.boomerangla.com/shows/hellcats |accessdate=July 5, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110701181209/http://la.boomerangla.com/shows/hellcats |archivedate=July 1, 2011 |df= }} [[New Zealand]],{{Cite news|title=TVNZ - Hellcats:|url=http://tvnz.co.nz/hellcats/index-group-4420708 |accessdate=February 17, 2012}} and [[Denmark]]. == Cancellation and possible reboot == According to the producer, [[Tom Welling]], he states that the reason of cancellation was due to the change of CW president of entertainment from Dawn Ostroff to Mark Pedowitz. He also said that there was a possibility of a reboot of the series with a new cast and cameos from the previous cast if enough fans continue to watch the original series on CW Seed.{{cite web|author=Rachael Ellenbogen |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/hellcats-coming-back-producer-tom-welling-reveals-cancelation-reason-2588890 |title=‘Hellcats’ Is Coming Back, Producer Tom Welling Reveals Cancelation Reason |publisher=Ibtimes.com |date= |accessdate=2018-05-19}} ==Streaming== The series is available to stream on [[The CW]]'s free digital-only network, [[The_CW#CW_Seed|CW Seed]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cwseed.com/shows/hellcats|title=Hellcats on CW Seed|accessdate=2018-11-04|work=CW Seed}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|1596356|Hellcats}} * {{Tv.com show|hellcats|Hellcats}} {{The CW programming}} {{78violet}} [[Category:2010 American television series debuts]] [[Category:2011 American television series endings]] [[Category:2010s American college television series]] [[Category:2010s American comedy-drama television series]] [[Category:2010s American teen drama television series]] [[Category:Aly & AJ]] [[Category:English-language television programs]] [[Category:Cheerleading television shows]] [[Category:The CW shows]] [[Category:Teenage pregnancy in television]] [[Category:Television series by CBS Television Studios]] [[Category:Television series by Warner Bros. Television]] [[Category:Television series produced in Vancouver]] [[Category:Television shows set in Tennessee]]

revision.text:
An '''ideograph''' or '''virtue word''' is a word frequently used in political discourse that uses an abstract concept to develop support for political positions. Such words are usually terms that do not have a clear definition but are used to give the impression of a clear meaning. An ideograph in rhetoric often exists as a building block or simply one term or short phrase that summarizes the orientation or attitude of an ideology. Such examples notably include <[[liberty]]>, <[[freedom]]>, <[[democracy]]> and <[[rights]]>. Rhetorical critics use chevrons or angle brackets (<>) to mark off ideographs. The term ideograph was coined by rhetorical scholar and critic [[Michael Calvin McGee]] (1980) describing the use of particular words and phrases as political language in a way that captures (as well as creates or reinforces) particular ideological positions. McGee sees the ideograph as a way of understanding of how specific, concrete instances of political discourse relate to the more abstract idea of political ideology.Jasinski, J. (2001). ''Sourcebook on rhetoric: Key concepts in contemporary rhetorical studies''. Thousand Oaks, CA: Sage Publications. Robertson defines ideographs as “political slogans or labels that encapsulate ideology in political discourse.”{{cite book|last=Jasinski|first=James|title=Sourcebook on rhetoric: Key concepts in contemporary rhetorical studies|year=2001|publisher=Sage Publications|location=Thousand Oaks, CA|page=308}} Meanwhile, [[Celeste Condit]] and [[John Lucaites]], influenced by McGee, explain, “Ideographs represent in condensed form the normative, collective commitments of the members of a public, and they typically appear in public argumentation as the necessary motivations or justifications for action performed in the name of the public.”{{cite book|last=Condit & Lucaites|first=C.M. & J.L.|title=Crafting equality: America’s Anglo-African word|year=1993|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago, IL|pages=xxii-xiii}} Ideographs are common in [[advertising]] and political discourse. ==Definition== McGee uses the term in his seminal article “The ‘Ideograph’: A Link Between Rhetoric and Ideology” which appeared in the ''[[Quarterly Journal of Speech]]'' in 1980.McGee, M.C. (1980). The “ideograph”: A link between rhetoric and ideology. ''Quarterly Journal of Speech, 66'', 1-16. He begins his essay by defining the practice of [[ideology]] as practice of political language in specific contexts—actual discursive acts by individual speakers and writers. The question this raises is how does this practice of [[ideology]] create social control. McGee’s answer to this is to say that “political language which manifests ideology seems characterized by slogans, a vocabulary of ‘ideographs’ easily mistaken for the technical terminology of [[political philosophy]].” He goes on to offer his definition of “ideograph”: “an ideograph is an ordinary-language term found in political discourse. It is a high order abstraction representing commitment to a particular but equivocal and ill-defined normative goal.” An ideograph, then, is not just any particular word or phrase used in political discourse, but one of a particular subset of terms that are often invoked in political discourse but which does not have a clear, univocal definition. Despite this, in their use, ideographs are often invoked precisely to give the sense of a clearly understood and shared meaning. This potency makes them the primary tools for shaping public decisions. It is in this role as the [[vocabulary]] for public values and decision-making that they are linked to [[ideology]]. == Examples == There is no absolute litmus test for what terms are or are not ideographs. Rather, this is a judgment that must be made through the study of specific examples of discourse. However, McGee (and others who have followed him) have identified several examples of ideographs or virtue words in Western liberal political discourse, such as <[[liberty]]>, <[[property]]>, <[[freedom of speech]]>, <[[religion]]>, and <[[Social equality|equality]]>. In each case, the term does not have a specific [[referent]]. Rather, each term refers to an [[abstraction]] which may have many different meanings depending on its [[context (language use)|context]]. It is in their mutability between circumstances that give the terms such rhetorical power. If the definition of a term such as <[[Social equality|equality]]> can be stretched to include a particular act or condition, then public support for that act or condition is likely to be stronger than it was previously. By encapsulating values which are perceived to be widely shared by the community, but which are in fact highly abstract and defined in very different ways by individuals, ideographs provide a potent persuasive tool for the political speaker. McGee offers the example of [[Richard Nixon]]’s attempt to defend his decision not to turn over documents to Congress during the [[Watergate scandal]] by invoking “the principle of [[confidentiality]].” Recognizing that his refusal to submit to Congress could be seen as a violation of the "[[rule of law]]", Nixon pitted "the principle of [[confidentiality]]” against the “[[rule of law]],” despite the fact that these two ideographs would, in the abstract, not likely be seen as in conflict with one another. Nixon, in an attempt to expand the understanding of “the principle of [[confidentiality]]” to cover his own specific refusal to cooperate with Congress, used the abstractness of the term to his benefit, claiming that right to confidentiality was the more central term. While the term has remained mostly in this sphere of academic [[rhetorical criticism]], some [[political consulting|political consultants]] and practitioners are becoming savvy to this art. Ideographs appear in [[advertising]] and [[political campaigns]] regularly, and are crucial to helping the public understand what is really being asked of them. For example, “[[Social equality|equality]]” is a term commonly used in political discourse and rarely defined. It can refer to a situation in which all people have the same opportunities, or a condition in which social resources are distributed uniformly to different individuals and groups.{{cite book|last=Jasinski|first=James|title=Sourcebook on rhetoric: Key concepts in contemporary rhetorical studies|year=2001|publisher=Sage Publications|location=Thousand Oaks, CA|page=310}} The former is the more commonly used definition in US history, according to Condit & Lucaites, although in a socialist or left-leaning political state, the term may refer foremost to the distribution of social resources. Condit and Lucaites depict the racial facet of equality as the dominant meaning in an American context of political discourse, since 1865.{{cite book|last=Condit & Lucaites|first=C.M. & J.L.|title=Crafting equality: America’s Anglo-African word|year=1993|publisher=University of Chicago Press|location=Chicago, IL|page=xvii}} Another important ideograph used specifically by U.S. presidents Barack Obama and George W. Bush after the 9/11 attacks is <[[terrorism]]>. The term does not have a clear or specific definition, but when applied to the context in the fear-stricken country after the devastating attacks in 2001, this term held significant weight and meaning to Americans all across the country. Kelly Long explores Obama’s discourse on the <[[War on Terror]]> and states that “by developing an ideological justification for the conflicts that the United States was involved in at the time, Obama remedied much of the damage done by the Bush administration”.{{cite journal|last1=Long|first1=Kelly|title="Terrorism" in the Age of Obama: The Rhetorical Evolution of President Obama's Discourse on the "War on Terror"|journal=Undergraduate Review|date=2013|volume=9|issue=1|page=90|url=http://vc.bridgew.edu/undergrad_rev/vol9/iss1/19|accessdate=29 September 2014}} Obama justified the <[[War on Terror]]> by addressing the nation and saying that in order to protect the <[[rule of law]]> and , we must fight against <[[terrorism]]>. Obama used this term to his advantage and made <[[terrorism]]> appear to be a common enemy and fighting back was the common cause.{{cite journal|last1=Long|first1=Kelly|title="Terrorism" in the Age of Obama: The Rhetorical Evolution of President Obama's Discourse on the "War on Terror"|journal=Undergraduate Review|date=2013|volume=9|issue=1|page=91|url=http://vc.bridgew.edu/undergrad_rev/vol9/iss1/19|accessdate=29 September 2014}} This use of the ideograph unified the country creating a sense of identity for American citizens, “defining what the nation stands for and against. The term divides those who are civilized from those who are uncivilized, those who defend economic freedom from those who would attack America’s way of life and those who support democracy from those who would disrupt it”.{{cite book|last1=Winkler|first1=Carol|title=In the Name of Terrorism: Presidents on Political Violence in the Post-World War II Era|date=2006|publisher=State University of New York Press|location=Albany, New York|page=2|edition=SUNY series on the Presidency|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hNXc1s_BKSoC&lpg=PA18&ots=YOlgZgkKFn&dq=carol%20winkler%20in%20the%20name%20of%20terrorism&pg=PA4#v=onepage&q=carol%20winkler%20in%20the%20name%20of%20terrorism&f=false|accessdate=29 September 2014}} Marouf Hasian discusses how key ideographs representative of a society’s commitments change over time, particularly in the name of <[[liberty]]>, <[[Social equality|equality]]>, or <[[privacy]]> epitomized in [[eugenics]]. From the 1900s-1930s, Americans justified the restriction of reproductive rights based on medical, social, economic, and political considerations, but were appalled when the [[Nazis]] used some of the same arguments in their creation of the “perfect race".{{cite book|last=Hasian|first=M.A.|title=The rhetoric of eugenics in Anglo-American thought|year=1996|publisher=University of Georgia Press|location=Athens, GA|page=139}} While rhetorical critics identify these terms as ideographs, political leaders viewed each other’s terms as "[[glittering generalities]],” as Lincoln first identified his opponent's words.{{cite web|last=Lincoln|first=Abraham|title=Lincoln to Henry Pierce|url=http://www.abrahamlincolnonline.org/lincoln/speeches/pierce.htm|publisher=The Abraham Lincoln Association|accessdate=25 March 2013}} In addition to practitioners, [[marketing|corporate marketing]] and [[political consulting]] use key terms in this way, concentrating on the [[image]] and [[brand management|branding]] of terms. For example, [[Frank Luntz]] tests audience reaction to certain words or phrases using dial technology, a mechanism which instantaneously shows moment by moment reactions to speeches or presentations. This research has been extremely beneficial to his clients, as they can utilize ideographs as "trigger words" in an [[advertising campaign]].{{cite book|last=Luntz|first=Frank|title=Words that work: It’s not what you say, it’s what people hear|year=2007|publisher=Hyperion|location=New York, NY}} ==Importance== There are three primary ways in which the concept of the ideograph is important to rhetorical critics. First, it suggests a way of studying political ideology using concrete instances of language use. By showing how looking at specific uses of key words and phrases in political language reveal underlying ideological commitments, McGee offers a concrete method for understanding the highly abstract concept of ideology. Second, the definition of the ideograph makes clear that the [[rhetoric|rhetorical study]] of a term is different from a legal, historical, or etymological study of a term. Unlike other perspectives that focus on how a term has changed over time, a rhetorical study of a term focuses on the forces involved in the creation of these meanings. In short, a rhetorical study of a term is the study of the use of that term in practice. This leads to a third key aspect of what the concept of the ideograph offers to rhetorical critics. McGee notes that the study of a term must not, and should not, be limited to its use in “formal discourse.” Instead, the critic is much more likely to gain a better understanding of an ideograph by looking at how it is used and depicted in movies, plays, and songs, as well as how it is presented in educational texts aimed at children. This moves the study of ideology beyond the limits of social philosophy or even political discourse as traditionally conceived (i.e., “great speeches by great men”). ==Cultural variability==
"An ideograph is a culturally biased, abstract word or phrase drawn from ordinary language, which serves a constitutional value for a historically situated collectivity."
There exists a culturally-specific understanding in each culture about what an ideograph means. Ideographs in rhetoric are culturally specific but recur inter-culturally; meaning the understanding of one ideograph can be used and interpreted differently across cultures. The idea may be different from culture to culture, but this doesn’t mean some aspects won’t be the same in one or more cultures. Such as the concept of [[femininity]] that exists cross-culturally to define ideas about women, yet one can expect these ideas from culture to culture. ==Critical use== At the end of his essay defining the ideograph, McGee says that
“A complete description of an ideology . . . will consist of (1) the isolation of a society’s ideographs, (2) the exposure and analysis of the [[Synchronic analysis|diachronic]] structure of every ideography, and (3) characterization of [[synchronic analysis|synchronic]] relationships among all the ideographs in a particular context.”
Such an exhaustive study of any ideology has yet to materialize, but many scholars have made use of the ideograph as a tool of understanding both specific [[rhetorical situations]] as well as a broader scope of ideological history. As a teacher, McGee himself made use of the ideograph as a tool for structuring the study of the rise of liberalism in British public address, focusing on ideographs such as <[[property]]>, <[[patriarchy]]>, <[[religion]]>, <[[liberty]]>. Other scholars have made a study of specific uses of ideographs such as <[[family values]]>Cloud, D. L. (1998). The rhetoric of : Scapegoating, utopia, and the privatization of social responsibility. ''Western Journal of Communication, 62'', 387-419. and <[[Egalitarianism|equality]]>.Condit, C. M. & Lucaites, J. L. (1993). ''Crafting quality: America’s Anglo-African word''. Chicago: University of Chicago Press. Some critics have gone beyond the idea that an ideograph must be a verbal symbol and have expanded the notion to include [[photographs]].Edwards, J. L. & Winkler, C. K. (1997). Representative forms and the visual ideograph: The Iwo Jima image in editorial cartoons. ''Quarterly Journal of Speech, 83'', 289-310. and objects represented in [[mass media]].Moore, M. P. (1996). The cigarette as representative ideograph in the debate over environmental tobacco smoke. ''Communication Monographs, 64'', 47-64. ==See also== *[[Essentially contested concept]] *[[Loaded language]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== * Pineda, R. D., & Sowards, S. K. (2007). Flag waving as visual argument: 2006 immigration demonstrations and cultural citizenship. ''Argumentation & Advocacy, 43''(3/4), 164-174. * * Potter, J. E. (2014). Brown-skinned outlaws: An ideographic analysis of "illegal(s)". ''Communication, Culture & Critique, 7''(2), 228-245. * {{Propaganda}} [[Category:Rhetoric]]

revision.text:
{{Expert-subject|Theatre|date=February 2009}}
The '''International Centre for Theatre Research''' sometimes also known as The International Centre for Theatre Creation was founded in 1970 by [[Peter Brook]] and [[Micheline Rozan]]. It is often abbreviated to the [[acronym]] CIRT as in French the group is called the Centre International de Recherche Théâtrale. The centre is a multicultural theatrical research and production company based out of the [[Bouffes du Nord]] theatre in Paris since 1974.<ref>'''The Continuum Companion to Twentieth Century Theatre'', edited Colin Chambers, Continuum, 2002, {{ISBN|0-8264-4959-X}}, Page 384</ref> The first three years of the company were taken up by exploring a fundamental theatrical question (see below)
== Funding == Brook had previously been sponsored for limited periods by [[Jean-Louis Barrault]] or the [[Royal Shakespeare Company|RSC]] (at the [[Roundhouse (venue)|Roundhouse]]). Brook and Rozan acquired sufficient funding to sustain Brook's work for three years. Working with a core company and several visiting collaborators. A budget of $1 million was established: $100,000 to set up the organization, and $300,000 for each year from 1971-1973{{Fact|date=February 2007}}. Money was raised from the French government and various international foundations ([[Ford Foundation]], [[Gulbenkian Foundation]] and [[Anderson Foundation]]s) Money also came from the government of [[Iran]] in the form of a commission for a work at the [[Shiraz, Iran|Shiraz]]/[[Persepolis]] festival in 1971. Work was begun even though the full three-year budget was not secured at the outset.
== First three-year journey == This multinational assembly of actors, dancers, musicians and other performers travelled widely in the Middle East and Africa in the early 1970s. This was as a three-year 'pilgrimage' to answer the question "What were the common stories, the recognizable shorthands, the instant abstractions, the shared outlines of story and character with which an international group could work?"{{Fact|date=February 2007}} On this three-year sojourn, they produced two major works ''[[Orghast]]'' I & II, performed in 1971 at the [[Shiraz Arts Festival]] in Iran in the [[Achaemenid]] ruins of [[Persepolis]] and [[Naqsh-e Rostam]], and ''[[The Conference of Birds]]'' developed in [[West Africa]] and completed in 1974 at [[Brooklyn Academy of Music|BAM]] in Brooklyn, New York.
==Similar organisations== *American Educational Theatre Association (1949) publishers of Educational Theatre Journal edited by [[Barnard Hewitt]] *American Society for Theatre Research (1956), publishers of ''Theatre Survey'' 1960<ref>The Oxford Companion to American Theatre - Page 27 0195169867 Gerald Bordman, Thomas S. Hischak - 2004 AMERICAN SOCIETY FOR THEATRE RESEARCH. Founded in 1956 and incorporated in 1967 as a tax-exempt organization under New Jersey law, its purpose is “to serve the needs of theatre historians in the practice of their profession, and ..."</ref>
==See also== *[[Théâtre des Bouffes du Nord]]
== References == <references/>
== External links == * [http://www.bouffesdunord.com bouffesdunord.com]
[[Category:Drama schools in France]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1969]] [[Category:Theatre companies in France]]

{{Infobox song | name = Knock Knock | cover = Monicaknockknock2.JPG | alt = | type = single | artist = [[Monica (singer)|Monica]] | album = [[After the Storm (Monica album)|After the Storm]] | released = September 2003 | format = [[Music download|Download]], [[DVD single|DVD]], [[CD single]] | recorded = 2003; [[Criteria Studios|The Hit Factory Criteria]]
([[Miami]], [[Florida]]) | studio = | venue = | genre = {{flat list | *[[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] *[[hip hop music|hip hop]]}} | length = 3:41 | label = [[J Records|J]] | writer = {{flat list| *[[Missy Elliott]] *Lee Hatim *[[Kanye West]] }} | producer = {{flat list| *Missy Elliott *Kanye West }} | prev_title = [[So Gone]] | prev_year = 2003 | next_title = [[Get It Off]] | next_year = 2003 }} "'''Knock Knock'''" is a song by American recording artist [[Monica (singer)|Monica]], taken from her fourth studio album ''[[After the Storm (Monica album)|After the Storm]]'' (2003). It was written and produced by rapper-producer [[Missy Elliott]] and commissioned following the delay and subsequent reconstruction of Monica's 2002 album, ''[[All Eyez on Me (Monica album)|All Eyez on Me]]''. One out of a handful of tracks which Elliott contributed, the song incorporates elements of 1970s-style [[soul music|soul]], as well as [[hip hop]], and is built around excerpts of the record "It's a Terrible Thing to Waste Your Love" as written by Lee Hatim and released by [[The Masqueraders]] in 1976. Rapper-producer [[Kanye West]], whose 2005 ''[[Freshmen Adjustment]]'' [[demo (music)|mixtape recording]] "Apologize" the track is based on, is listed as the song's co-producer. [[J Records]] released "Knock Knock", alongside fellow Elliott production "[[Get It Off]]," as one of two singles following leading single "[[So Gone]]" during the third quarter of 2003. The song was lauded by critics, who praised its streetwise production and Monica's rap part on the track. A moderate success at the charts, it peaked at number 75 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] and number 24 on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]] chart. Its accompanying [[music video]], directed by [[Chris Robinson (director)|Chris Robinson]], was filmed as a two-part story with "So Gone". ==Writing and recording== "Knock Knock" was written and produced by [[Missy Elliott]] for Mass Confusion Productions, with additional production by [[Kanye West]].{{cite AV media notes |title=After the Storm |publisher=J Records |others=Monica |titlelink=After the Storm (Monica album) |year=2003}} Lee Hatim is also credited in the song because it contains excerpts from The Masquerader' 1975 single, "It's a Terrible Thing to Waste Your Love." West previously [[sample (music)|sampled]] the track in his own [[demo (music)|demo recording]], "Apologize", which was later released on his 2005 mixtape ''[[Freshmen Adjustment]]''. "Knock Knock" was recorded by Carlos Bedoya at [[Criteria Studios|The Hit Factory Criteria]] in [[Miami, Florida]] with further assistance from [[Marcella Araica]]. Scott Kieklak [[Audio mixing (recorded music)|mixed]] the song, while [[Audio mastering|mastering]] was overseen by [[Tom Coyne (music engineer)|Tom Coyne]]. Elliott also provided additional vocals. The song is one out of three Elliott-produced records on ''[[After the Storm (Monica album)|After the Storm]]'', commissioned by [[J Records]] head and executive producer [[Clive Davis]] after the release of Elliott's acclaimed studio album ''[[Under Construction (Missy Elliott album)|Under Construction]]'' (2002) and the delay of Monica's original third studio album ''[[All Eyez on Me (Monica album)|All Eyez on Me]]'' the year before.{{cite web|first1=Shaheem |last1=Reid |first2=Quddus |last2=Philippe |first3=Curtis |last3=Waller |title=Monica Revises Leaked LP With Help From Missy Elliott |work=[[MTV News]] |publisher=[[VH1]].com |url=http://www.vh1.com/artists/news/1471325/20030416/monica.jhtml |accessdate=2009-02-12 |date=2003-04-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080111143229/http://www.vh1.com/artists/news/1471325/20030416/monica.jhtml |archivedate=2008-01-11 |df= }} It was conceived during a studio session week in Miami in early 2003, and was produced as a [[sequel]] to "[[So Gone]]," another Elliott track. In an interview with ''[[MTV News]]'' at the 2003 [[BET Awards]], Monica stated that "'Knock Knock' is [...] like a follow-up to 'So Gone,' just saying that, 'All right, we went through all that stuff, now it's time for you to get lost. This is the end of the road for you.' So, it's kind of like a 'get back' record."{{cite web|first=Corey|last=Moss|title='Knock Knock,' Who's There? Monica And Missy Elliott, Bringing The Heat |work=[[MTV News]]|publisher=[[Viacom]]|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1473460/monica-brings-heat-with-new-single.jhtml|date=2003-07-07|accessdate=2009-04-12}} Commenting on the recording process, she added: "She [Elliott] doesn't have any fear [...] When she goes in the studio, her goal is to be creative and to give something new and she could care less what else is current. And she creates new trends by doing that." ==Release and reception== [[File:Kanye at ACL Music Festival 1 (crop).jpg|thumb|upright|right|140px|Rapper [[Kanye West]] is credited as a co-producer on the track.]] "Knock Knock" received generally positive reviews from music critics. [[Allmusic]] editor Andy Kellman felt that the song, along with Elliott's other contributions on the album, provides "a bulk of the most exciting material, with just the right amount of swagger added to the singer's more wide-eyed personality of the '90s."Kellman, Andy. "[{{Allmusic|class=album|id=r643951|pure_url=yes}} After the Storm – Monica]". [[Allmusic]]. Retrieved on 2010-03-12. Melisa Tang from ''The Situation'' called Monica's vocals "exceptional" and felt that she "does a pretty decent job" at [[emcee]]ing on the track.{{cite web|url=http://www.thesituation.co.uk/reviews/monica_review.html |title=After the Storm Review |last=Tang |first=Melisa |work=The Situation |accessdate=2013-06-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090109215114/http://www.thesituation.co.uk/reviews/monica_review.html |archivedate=2009-01-09 |df= }} ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]''{{'}}s Vanessa Jones declared "Knock Knock" a "streetwise party anthem."{{cite journal|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,Prometheus Global Media,464194,00.html|title=After the Storm Review|last=Jones|first=Vanessa|journal=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=July 18, 2003|pages=76–77|accessdate=2012-10-06}} ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' ranked the song among the album's highlights.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dA4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA53&dq=%22AFTER+THE+STORM%22+REVIEW+%22KNOCK+KNOCK%22&hl=de&sa=X&ei=pvG4UaLpEoGStAbWnIDQBw&ved=0CDIQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22AFTER%20THE%20STORM%22%20REVIEW%20%22KNOCK%20KNOCK%22&f=false|title=Essentials: Review|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|publisher=[[Prometheus Global Media]]|date=2003-06-28|accessdate=2013-06-06}} First released in the United States, "Knock Knock" debuted at number 89 on the national [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart in the week of October 2, 2003, the fifth-highest debut of the week.{{Cite web|title=The Billboard Hot 100 (2004-08-28)|url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/charts/search/detailed_chart_display.jsp?g=s&cd=Aug-28-2004&f=The_Billboard_Hot_100&model.chartId=3055081|work=Billboard|accessdate=2008-07-29}} The single remained eighteen weeks on the chart, but as it failed to climb any higher during its runwith peak positions at number 75, the song eventually became Monica's lowest-charting, video-accompanied single on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 since 1999's "[[Street Symphony]]". Just as predecessor, "[[So Gone]]," the track was more successful on ''Billboard'''s component charts: "Knock Knock" reached number 24 on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Songs]] chart and number 37 on the [[Hot R&B/Hip-Hop Airplay]] chart. The remix of the single featured producer [[Kanye West]]. ==Music video== The [[music video]] for "Knock Knock" was shot by director [[Chris Robinson (director)|Chris Robinson]], and produced by Dawn Rose for Partizan Entertainment. It was filmed in various locations throughout Miami, Florida on in mid-late July 2003, and widely serves as the sequel ("Part II") to the video for "[[So Gone]]", the first single released from ''After the Storm''. The video features a second appearance by actor [[Derek Luke (actor)|Derek Luke]] (Antwone Fisher), who plays Monica's boyfriend, and intercuts a clip of simultaneously released club single "[[Get It Off]]" with a dance scene. The "Knock Knock" video premiered worldwide in July 2003. It charted well on several video-chart countdowns, including peak positions of number 3 on [[Black Entertainment Television|BET]]'s ''[[106 & Park]]''. There are two versions of the video, both featuring the same premise but with certain different scenes. ==Formats and track listings== {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} '''CD single'''{{cite web |url=http://www.discogs.com/Monica-So-Gone/release/626097|title=Monica – Knock Knock (CD, Maxi-Single, Promo) |publisher=[[Discogs]] |accessdate=2013-05-15}} # "Knock Knock" (radio edit) – 3:31 # "Knock Knock" (album version) – 3:41 # "Knock Knock" (instrumental) – 3:31 {{col-2}} ;DVD single # "Knock Knock"/"[[Get It Off]]" (video) # "[[So Gone]]" (video) # "Knock Knock" (live video from session@AOL) {{col-end}} ==Credits and personnel== Credits adapted from the liner notes of ''After the Storm''. {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} * [[Marcella Araica]] – audio engineering * Monica Arnold – [[Vocal|lead vocals]], background vocals * Carlos Bedoya – [[audio recording|recording]] * [[Tom Coyne (music engineer)|Tom Coyne]] – [[Master recording|mastering]] {{col-2}} * [[Missy Elliott]] – [[Music production|production]], additional vocals * Scott Kieklak – [[Audio mixing (recorded music)|mixing]] * [[Kanye West]] – [[Music production|co-production]] {{col-end}} ==Charts== ===Weekly charts=== {| class="wikitable sortable" ! Chart (2003) !! Peak
position |- {{singlechart|Billboardhot100|75|artist=Monica|song=Knock Knock|artistid=88033|accessdate=2011-05-23}} |- {{singlechart|Billboardrandbhiphop|24|artist=Monica|song=Knock Knock|artistid=88033|accessdate=2011-05-23}} |- |} ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.monica.com/}} {{Monica songs}} [[Category:2003 singles]] [[Category:Monica (singer) songs]] [[Category:Music videos directed by Chris Robinson (director)]] [[Category:Song recordings produced by Kanye West]] [[Category:Songs written by Kanye West]] [[Category:Songs written by Missy Elliott]] [[Category:2003 songs]] [[Category:J Records singles]] [[Category:Sequel songs]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=August 2018}}
'''Le Roy Benjamin''' (1917–1997) was the sculptor and manipulator of the marionettes as well as the voice impersonator for a vaudeville and television act called the '''Le Roy Brothers Marionettes'''.
==Early life== [Http://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Le_Roy_Benjamin,_Danny_Thomas,_Danny_Thomas_marionette.tif]<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1093/anb/9780198606697.article.1803319|title=Thomas, Danny (1912-1991), entertainer and philanthropist|last=Marshall|first=Stephen G.|date=2000-02|publisher=Oxford University Press|series=American National Biography Online}}</ref> Le Roy was born in Chicago to father Solomon and mother Minnie or "Mae". His father was of Persian descent and his mother of Polish descent. Etta Benjamin (1924–2009) was his wife, his business partner, his stage audio and lighting expert, and a fellow accomplished modern artist. She was born in St. Louis to Ida and Nat Perkins who come from Polish/Russian descent.
At fourteen years old, Le Roy began working at an ice cream shop during the Depression to help his family. He always liked to work with hands. He began performing his own puppet shows for children in a Chicago candy shop. His first stage act experience began in 1939 at the New York World's Fair<ref>{{Citation|last=Medicus (P.)|title=[Amateur film: Medicus collection: New York World's Fair, 1939-40] (Reel 3) (Part III)|date=April 1942|url=https://archive.org/details/Medicusc1939_10|accessdate=2018-01-22}}</ref> when he helped a marionette act. Then he went on the road with his own marionette act.
==Le Roy Brothers Marionettes== His Le Roy Brothers Marionette act required two people on the stage to manipulate the marionettes, initially included his brother, Melvin Benjamin, as the other marionettist and later his brother-in- law, Earl Perkins, who replaced Melvin. He married his wife, Etta Perkins in 1946, who managed the behind-the-scenes audio and lights production.
The Le Roy Brothers Marionettes (1939–1955) was one of the most celebrated and requested vaudeville acts in America, showcasing the top vaudeville stars. The marionettes which astounded audiences in disbelief included lifelike comedians and actors: humorous Danny Thomas, Jimmy Durante performing with piano,<ref name=autogenerated2>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RAsEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA15&lpg=PA15|title=Billboard|last=Inc|first=Nielsen Business Media|date=1953-03-14|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.}}</ref> Dean Martin & Jerry Lewis; and drummer Gene Krupa whose drums would explode from being played with .38 caliber blanks going off,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=sBEEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT18&lpg=PT18|title=Billboard|last=Inc|first=Nielsen Business Media|date=1945-08-04|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.}}</ref> amongst other favorite characters such as the original woman on the moon, breakaway detaching fluorescent skeletons and jitterbug dancers, and a clown blowing up balloons.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iRgEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT33&lpg=PT33|title=Billboard|last=Inc|first=Nielsen Business Media|date=1946-01-26|publisher=Nielsen Business Media, Inc.}}</ref> They would often break the "third wall" and bring the marionettes into the audience as part of their unique routine. This is one example why most consider Le Roy the master in his craft. He is considered the best marionettist of all time.
The Le Roy Brothers Marionettes performed at all of the popular state of the art theatres of their time including: Chez Paree, 5100 Club, Club Royale, Club Carnival, Roxy Theatre New York, RKO Palace Theatre, the Olympia, and The Normandie Roof. Their act opened for [[Danny Thomas]], [[Rosemary Clooney]], amongst others; while [[Joan Blondell]] occasionally participated with the marionette routine. Not very many vaudeville acts made the transition from live stage to television. The Le Roy Brothers Marionettes was one of the acts that did from television's "The Toast of the Town"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/shows/toast-of-the-town/episodes/|title=Toast of the Town|last=TV.com|website=TV.com|access-date=2018-01-22}}</ref> (aka: The Ed Sullivan Show) Season 2 Episode 47 aired on August 6, 1950,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/shows/toast-of-the-town/august-6-1950-115063/|title=Toast of the Town: August 6, 1950|last=TV.com|website=TV.com|access-date=2018-01-22}}</ref> had their own network TV show "Sandy Strong" sponsored by Ovaltine,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ss21AwAAQBAJ&pg=PT69&lpg=PT69|title=Kids' TV: The First Twenty-Five Years|last=Fischer|first=Stuart|date=2014-06-10|publisher=Open Road Media|isbn=9781497633902}}</ref> and was on "The Mickey Mouse Club"<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.originalmmc.com/circusacts.html|title=Original Mickey Mouse Club Show: Circus Acts|website=www.originalmmc.com|access-date=2018-01-22}}</ref> Season 1 in 1955 <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.originalmmc.com/images/Circusacts/leroymarionettes.jpg|title=Mickey Mouse Club - Season 1|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> With the transition to TV, some vaudeville performers became even more popular to become household names and segue onward to film. Those performers include Danny Thomas, Jimmy Durante, Rosemary Clooney, Dean Martin & Jerry Lewis…the very same people who were perhaps first immortalized by the Le Roy Brothers Marionettes.
Danny Thomas and Le Roy created the closest relationship. In the early years, when Danny was in vaudeville as a stand-up comedian, Danny would always ask Le Roy to be his opening act. Le Roy opened for Danny for two years in a row at the Chez Paree in Chicago. Then Danny went on to be a famous television actor/producer. Later, he founded the [[St. Jude Children's Research Hospital]]. Every time at the hospital's annual fundraising event, Danny would immediately seek out Le Roy in the audience as a true testament to their enduring friendship that lasted decades. Danny wrote a musical interlude about Le Roy's act singing "I'm just a marionette tied to the strings of your heart". Le Roy also fostered close friendships with Broadway/TV actor Jack Soo<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jacksoo.com/trailer.htm|title=You Don't Know Jack: The Jack Soo Story|website=www.jacksoo.com|access-date=2018-01-22}}</ref> and singer Nat King Cole and amongst others.
The most respectable agent would often reach out to Le Roy to pitch new projects. Reporters of that time stated the Le Roy Brother Marionettes performance was "the best marionette act in show business".<ref name=autogenerated2 /><ref name=autogenerated1 />
==Later life== After vaudeville, LeRoy and Etta continued their creative entrepreneurial success as a framing and fine art<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.askart.com/artist/Etta_Benjamin_Cien/11275165/Etta_Benjamin_Cien.aspx|title=Etta Benjamin Cien - Artist, Fine Art Prices, Auction Records for Etta Benjamin Cien|website=www.askart.com|access-date=2018-01-22}}</ref> business called the Hillside House of Originals,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/1970/01/24/forward|title=Forward!|last=Ross|first=Lillian|date=1970-01-17|work=The New Yorker|access-date=2018-01-22|issn=0028-792X}}</ref> and then they leased out their production space to BET (Black Entertainment Television) for several years.
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Benjamin, Le Roy}} [[Category:1917 births]] [[Category:1997 deaths]] [[Category:People from Chicago]] [[Category:American people of Polish descent]] [[Category:American people of Iranian descent]] [[Category:American puppeteers]] [[Category:Vaudeville performers]]

page.title: Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (video game)

revision.comment: /* Soundtrack */
revision.text:
{{Infobox video game |title = Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole |image = Legend of the Guardians-The Owls of GaHoole (video game).jpg |image_size = 250px |developer = [[Krome Studios]]
[[Tantalus Media]] (Nintendo DS) |publisher = [[Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment]] |designer = |composer = [[Winifred Phillips]] |released = {{vgrelease|NA|September 14, 2010}}{{vgrelease|AUS|September 29, 2010}}{{vgrelease|EU|October 8, 2010}} |modes = |genre = [[Combat flight simulator]] |platforms = [[PlayStation 3]]
[[Xbox 360]]
[[Wii]]
[[Nintendo DS]] }} '''''Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole''''' is a [[video game]] developed by [[Krome Studios]] ([[Tantalus Media]] for the Nintendo DS) and published by [[Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment]], released on September 14, 2010. It is based on the [[Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole|film of the same name]], and includes some elements from the [[Guardians of Ga'Hoole|books]]. The game is available for [[PlayStation 3]], [[Wii]] and [[Xbox 360]] as well as [[Nintendo DS]]. The game takes place during the events of the movie. ==Plot== ===Introduction=== The story of the game follows the tale of Shard and his friends. The story coincides with the plot of the movie. In the Canyonlands, The Glauxian Monks worshiped the owl god Glaux, hidden away from the strifes of life. Surtr and the Pure Ones had been defeated years ago by Lyze of Kiel and the land had been returned to peace. However, during the watch of a young guard named Grettir, the Monastery was attacked by Hagsfiends. After losing most of what he knew as his family, he was plagued of guilt and many others who had heard the story branded him a traitor and a coward. After many years of isolation, Grettir took a mate named Lygeia and had an egg together. On the night that the owlet was to hatch, the nest of Grettir was attacked by owls and they killed the Grettir and his mate, but the owlet, now named Shard, survived. ===Tutorial=== Shard charges into battle, at the side of Allomere, destroying catapults and defeating hagsfiends. But as the battle continues, Shard gets surrounded by hagsfiends and as they collapse in for the kill, Shard wakes up from his dream and we are introduced to our two main characters, Shard and Parzival. Allomere, a character from the Legends of the Guardians movie is the ryb for both of the students. As Shard takes offense to Parzival insulting his father, it escalates into a fight between the two owls and Allomere gives the flint mops, or work for punishment. Ezylryb asks to take care of flint mops. The flint mop is lighting torches for the Great Tree and just as Shard and Parzival finish their job, the Search and Rescue chaw comes in with a band of owlets, later revealed to be Soren, Gylfie, Twilight and Digger, and they are being attacked by a murder of crows. After Shard and Parvizal had cleared away the crows, the owlets went to parliament to tell them the story St. Aegolius and what the Pure Ones were doing. Parliament came to the decision that Allomere would go to the canyonlands to verify the truth of Soren's claim. After the decision, Ezylryb gave Shard the task of secret missions as a Guardian and set off to the Desert Kingdom of Kuneer. ===The Desert of Kuneer=== Shard is tasked with finding an eagle named Streak and finding out the cause for the disappearance of young owlets in the area. Shard and Parzival find Streak imprisoned by bats allied with the Pure Ones and free him. Streak becomes Shard's wingman along with Parzival and they go on missions for the rest of the story. Streak reveals that the owlet snatching is true and that the bats are being rewarded for their loyalty by being given some Non-Tyto owlets. Shard and his band go on a mission to find the hideout by destroying bat sanctuaries to make them reveal the location of the hideout. After one of the bats told Streak it was east of the sanctuary to find the secret hideout filled with bats and Pure Ones. After they defeat the defenses of the hideout, reinforcements come to defend the hideout, which guarantees the rumors of the owlets being held there. The group finds some bats still taking owlets from nests and after rescuing them, the group realizes that these problems aren't going to stop unless they take the fight to the bats. After a small attack on the Streak's Nest, the band goes and devises a plan to force the bats out of the hiding places within the compound by forcing them out with fire. The battle becomes more intense as the hideouts are burnt out and the band defeats the defenses. After what seemed like a victory, the Bat Chieftain comes out of hiding to fight with the protagonists. After vanquishing both the Chieftain and what remained of the bats, they free a wandering hermit named Uriah, who tells them that the Pure Ones are working with the bats to gain control of a mysterious substance called flecks. He asks to be part of Shard's band and becomes one of his wingmen and the band returns to the Great Tree to inform them about what was happening in the Desert of Kuneer. ===The Forest Kingdom of Tyto=== Shard is tasked with finding the activities of the Pure Ones have in the Forest of Tyto and finding locals who could know what they are doing. Shard and Parzival follow a squadron of Pure Ones who lead them to a prison with resistance fighters locked up in them. ==Gameplay== According to ''[[GameSpot]]'', the gameplay is airborne combat. The player locks on to enemy owls or structures, and the player has the option to attack. If the player chooses to do so, the player-controlled owl will "go zooming toward your enemy and wallop it with your claws" as stated in the review. ''GameSpot'' also stated that there are some parts where the player has to navigate through gates in a specific amount of time. The player can choose between four owl species to play as before the game starts, each with its own set of advantages and disadvantages. These include [[barn owl]], [[spotted owl]], [[great gray owl]], and [[great horned owl]]. ==Soundtrack== The original musical soundtrack of the ''Legend of the Guardians'' video game was composed by [[Winifred Phillips]]{{cite web |url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/album/legend-guardians-the-owls/id393012164 |title=Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole (Original Videogame Soundtrack) by Winifred Phillips on iTunes |website=[[iTunes Store]] |accessdate=October 26, 2010}} and produced by [[Winnie Waldron]].{{cite web |url=http://www.winifredphillips.com/videos/video-quicktime-1.htm |title=Winifred Phillips, Video |website=[[Winifred Phillips]] |accessdate=October 26, 2010}} The soundtrack was released on iTunes by [[WaterTower Music]], a division of Warner Bros. Entertainment. The second track on the album, "With Hearts Sublime", is a winner of the 2010 Hollywood Music in Media Award in the category "Best Original Song: Video Game".{{cite web |url=http://www.hmmawards.com/hmma-2010-winners/ |title=HMMA 2010 Winners |website=[[Hollywood Music in Media Awards]] |accessdate=January 1, 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160403114015/http://www.hmmawards.com:80/hmma-2010-winners/ |archivedate=April 3, 2016 |deadurl=yes}} ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | MC = X360: 60/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-360/legend-of-the-guardians-the-owls-of-gahoole |title=Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole for Xbox 360 Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=2018-06-29}}
PS3: 62/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/playstation-3/legend-of-the-guardians-the-owls-of-gahoole |title=Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole for PlayStation 3 Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=2018-06-29}}
WII: 54/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/wii/legend-of-the-guardians-the-owls-of-gahoole |title=Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole for Wii Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=2018-06-29}}
DS: 33/100{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/ds/legend-of-the-guardians-the-owls-of-gahoole |title=Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole for DS Reviews |website=[[Metacritic]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=2018-06-29}} | GI = X360: 7.25/10{{cite web |url=https://www.gameinformer.com/games/legend_of_the_guardians_the_owls_of_gahoole/b/xbox360/archive/2010/09/14/air-combat-goes-back-to-the-basics.aspx |title=Legend of the Guardians Review |last=Miller |first=Matt |date=2010-09-14 |website=[[Game Informer]] |publisher=[[GameStop]] |accessdate=2018-06-29}} | GSpot = 6/10{{cite web |url=https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/legend-of-the-guardians-the-owls-of-gahoole-review/1900-6276433/ |title=Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole Review |last=VanOrd |first=Kevin |date=2010-09-17 |website=[[GameSpot]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=2010-10-18}}{{cite web |url=https://www.gamespot.com/reviews/legend-of-the-guardians-the-owls-of-gahoole-review/1900-6276434/ |title=Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole Review |last=VanOrd |first=Kevin |date=2010-09-17 |website=[[GameSpot]] |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]] |accessdate=2018-06-29}} }} ''Legend of the Guardians: The Owls of Ga'Hoole'' received largely mixed and average reviews. According to [[Metacritic]], the Xbox 360 version has an average critic score of 60 out of 100 based on 13 reviews. While acknowledging its gameplay and other elements as commendable, the majority of critics noted the game's short play time and replay value as a major pitfall. ''GameSpot'' gave the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 versions a 6/10 rating.{{r|GSpotX360|GSpotPS3}} ''[[Game Informer]]'' awarded it 7.25 out of 10 and said "Though limited in scope and complexity, the game does everything it sets out to do and remains a fun family diversion throughout". ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Legend Of The Guardians: The Owls Of Ga'hoole (Video Game)}} [[Category:2010 video games]] [[Category:Action-adventure games]] [[Category:Fantasy video games]] [[Category:Guardians of Ga'Hoole]] [[Category:Nintendo DS games]] [[Category:Platform games]] [[Category:PlayStation 3 games]] [[Category:Side-scrolling video games]] [[Category:Video games based on films]] [[Category:Krome Studios games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Australia]] [[Category:Video games featuring anthropomorphic characters]] [[Category:Video games scored by Winifred Phillips]] [[Category:Wii games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]] [[Category:Warner Bros. Interactive Entertainment games]]
