Prabhu Raja Cholan, who would later direct the film ''[[Karuppampatti]]'' (2013), worked as an assistant director in this film.{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/audio-beat-karuppampatti/article3790832.ece |title=Audio Beat: Karuppampatti |newspaper=The Hindu |author=S. R. Ashok Kumar |date=18 August 2012 |accessdate=13 January 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113074639/http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/audio-beat-karuppampatti/article3790832.ece |archivedate=13 January 2015 |deadurl=no}} Rajinikanth's daughter [[Soundarya Rajinikanth|Soundarya]] worked as a graphics designer, creating the title for this film; she had earlier worked in the same position on two of her father's films – ''[[Baba (2002 film)|Baba]]'' (2002) and ''[[Chandramukhi]]'' (2005).{{Sfn|Ramachandran|2014|page=234}} [[K. V. Anand]] was hired as the cinematographer in August 2005.{{cite web |url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/14sld1.htm |title=The man who shot ''Sivaji'' – Slide 1 |publisher=Rediff |author=Shobha Warrier |date=14 May 2007 |accessdate=25 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150425154436/http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/14sld1.htm |archivedate=25 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} [[Manish Malhotra]] was responsible for designing the film's costumes,{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/too-haute-to-handle/article2243878.ece |title=Too haute to handle? |work=The Hindu |date=19 April 2007 |accessdate=25 April 2015 |author=T. Krthika Reddy |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150425151005/http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/too-haute-to-handle/article2243878.ece |archivedate=25 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} while [[Anthony (film editor)|Anthony]] and [[Thota Tharani]] were the editor and art director respectively.{{Sfn|Dhananjayan|2011|page=292}} Additional make-up for Rajinikanth was done by make-up artist [[Banu (makeup artist)|Banu]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/readying-the-boss/article2250291.ece |title=Readying the boss |work=The Hindu |date=12 July 2007 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |author=Sudha Umashanker |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426060042/http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/readying-the-boss/article2250291.ece |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} === Filming === [[Principal photography]] commenced on 28 November 2005 with a [[Puja (Hinduism)|puja]] at AVM Productions. The film's launch was a secret event, with only pivotal members of the cast and crew being called for the event's attendance. The first schedule of ''Sivaji'' began on 14 December 2005 with the song "Vaaji Vaaji" featuring Rajinikanth and Saran being shot at [[Ramoji Film City]] in [[Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh|Hyderabad]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sify.com/movies/sivaji-starts-rolling-news-tamil-kkfvxocbcaisi.html |title='Sivaji' starts rolling! |publisher=Sify |date=14 December 2005 |accessdate=25 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150425141709/http://www.sify.com/movies/sivaji-starts-rolling-news-tamil-kkfvxocbcaisi.html |archivedate=25 April 2015 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/16slide2.htm |title=Thota Tharani on ''Sivaji'' – Slide 2 |publisher=Rediff |date=16 May 2007 |author=Shobha Warrier |accessdate=29 December 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150425141813/http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/16slide2.htm |archivedate=25 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} The idea of shooting at Ramoji Film City was suggested to Shankar by Tharani who felt that the place offered a lot of scope for him to utilise his skills and experience as an art director. "Vaaji Vaaji" was picturised with an intention to showcase a [[Babylon]]ian palace setting when Shankar requested Tharani to show "a palace with lots of colour". Tharani created a four-storey Babylonian palace to accommodate 80 dancers and 100 junior artists for the number.{{cite web |url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/16slide3.htm |title=Thota Tharani on ''Sivaji'' – Slide 3 |publisher=Rediff |date=16 May 2007 |accessdate=25 April 2015 |author=Shobha Warrier |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150425153544/http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/16slide3.htm |archivedate=25 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} Shooting of the number, which according to K. V. Anand was filmed in [[Super 35]] [[Film|motion picture]] [[film format]], was completed in eight days.{{cite web |url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/14sld2.htm |title=The man who shot ''Sivaji'' – Slide 2 |publisher=Rediff |author=Shobha Warrier |date=14 May 2007 |accessdate=25 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150425143229/http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/14sld2.htm |archivedate=25 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} [[G. Dhananjayan]] mentions in his book ''The Best of Tamil Cinema'' that {{INR}}35 million{{efn|name=exchange2007}} was spent on the song's making.{{Sfn|Dhananjayan|2011|page=294}} {{quote box | quote = I decided to have a glass dome depicting four seasons. But Shankar was specific, saying he wanted the desert and the flowers look. So, we decided to have desert on one side and rocks, waterfalls and flowers on the other. | source =— Thota Tharani, on his experience of designing the set for the "Sahana" number.{{cite web |url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/16slide4.htm |title=Thota Tharani on ''Sivaji'' – Slide 4 |publisher=Rediff |date=16 May 2007 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |author=Shobha Warrier |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426015423/http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/16slide4.htm |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} | align = right | width = 35% }} Tharani described the set designing for the song "Sahana", which was also shot at Ramoji Film City, as "extremely challenging". After listening to the lyrics of the song which speaks of the four traditional [[Season|calendar seasons]], Tharani thought of using a concept titled ''Living in Seasons'', which he used at a [[symposium]] held in Japan.{{efn|''[[The Hindu]]'' gives the year the symposium was held as 1991,{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-fridayreview/for-me-every-set-is-a-challenge/article2273078.ece |title='For me, every set is a challenge' |work=The Hindu |date=20 July 2007 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |author=Savitha Gautham |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426014650/http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-fridayreview/for-me-every-set-is-a-challenge/article2273078.ece |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} while [[Rediff.com]] states the year to be 1992.}} For the set's design which depicted the four seasons, Tharani proposed three concepts – a traditional Japanese house, a contemporary house and a futuristic house. Shankar chose the futuristic house concept, which consisted of three domes in the shapes of a square, a circle and a pyramid adjacent to one another. The circular dome had a pathway around it and water falling from a 50 feet high rock, which would seep under the set. Tharani made use of [[Poly(methyl methacrylate)|acrylic glass]] and [[glass|normal glass]] with the former being implemented on the floor to make the dance movements more easier to perform. Construction of the set for the number was completed in 30 days.{{cite web |url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/16slide5.htm |title=Thota Tharani on ''Sivaji'' – Slide 5 |publisher=Rediff |date=16 May 2007 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |author=Shobha Warrier |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426022645/http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/16slide5.htm |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} In addition to these two songs, Tharani contributed to similar creations for the music store where Tamizhselvi works as a saleswoman, the street surrounding the music store, the [[warehouse]] behind the music store, the interior portions of Thamizhselvi's house and Adiseshan's office room. The music shop was designed in the [[Victorian architecture]] style, while the warehouse was constructed at AVM Productions with the fight sequence being filmed there as well.{{cite web |url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/16slide6.htm |title=Thota Tharani on ''Sivaji'' – Slide 6 |publisher=Rediff |date=16 May 2007 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |author=Shobha Warrier |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426043332/http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/16slide6.htm |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} Filming of another action sequence in an open-air theatre, which was also designed by Tharani, took place for approximately 15–20 days.{{cite web |url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/16slide7.htm |title=Thota Tharani on ''Sivaji'' – Slide 7 |publisher=Rediff |date=16 May 2007 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |author=Shobha Warrier |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426045038/http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/16slide7.htm |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} K. V. Anand used [[balloon light]]s brought from a French company [[Balloon light#Airstar|Airstar Space Lighting]] for the sequence.{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/lights-camera-attraction/article2241809.ece |title=Lights, camera, attraction |work=The Hindu |date=8 March 2007 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |author=S. R. Ashok Kumar |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426051145/http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-features/tp-metroplus/lights-camera-attraction/article2241809.ece |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} The interior portions of Thamizhselvi's house was designed using clippings of flats constructed by the [[Tamil Nadu Housing Board]].{{cite web |url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/16slide8.htm |title=Thota Tharani on ''Sivaji'' – Slide 8 |publisher=Rediff |date=16 May 2007 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |author=Shobha Warrier |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426045051/http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/16slide8.htm |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} [[File:Guggenheim-bilbao-jan05.jpg|thumb|left|The Guggenheim Museum which features in "Style".]] The "Style" segment was filmed in May 2006 at the [[Frank Gehry]]-designed [[Guggenheim Museum Bilbao|Guggenheim Museum]] in [[Bilbao]], [[Spain]],{{cite web |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/sivaji-the-boss-a-comeback-for-rajnikant/1/155493.html |title=The Boss |work=[[India Today]] |date=9 July 2007 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |author=Lakshmi Subramanian |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426062038/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/sivaji-the-boss-a-comeback-for-rajnikant/1/155493.html |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |df=}}{{cite web |url=http://www.sify.com/movies/sivaji-goes-to-spain-news-tamil-kkfvlijchaisi.html |title=Sivaji goes to Spain! |publisher=Sify |date=17 May 2006 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426062024/http://www.sify.com/movies/sivaji-goes-to-spain-news-tamil-kkfvlijchaisi.html |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} as well as the [[City of Arts and Sciences]].{{cite book |url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=-AegCwAAQBAJ&pg=PA92&lpg=PA92&dq=Nala+Damayanthi+kamal+scene&source=bl&ots=9HjWFxfVSV&sig=DNVBQ5o1sg2m4goRH3v830zPsBQ&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjt17qVlOzRAhXCqI8KHco_AEw4HhDoAQgYMAA#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Tradition, Culture and Aesthetics in Contemporary Asian Cinema |publisher=[[Routledge]] |year=2016 |p=92 |author=Peter C. Pugsley}} The fair look of Rajinikanth's character in the segment was created using [[computer-generated imagery]], which was performed by [[V. Srinivas Mohan]], the head of the Chennai-based firm Indian Artists. K. V. Anand re-shot every single movement of Rajinikanth with a British woman named Jacky, who was also one of the song's background dancers. All the shots featuring Rajinikanth in the song and those featuring Jacky were scanned in [[4K resolution]] to enhance their clarity after which Jacky's skin colour was digitally implemented onto Rajinikanth's skin.{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/friday-review/music/success-so-special/article30768.ece |title=Success so special |work=The Hindu |date=8 October 2009 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |author=Malathi Rangarajan |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426073632/http://www.thehindu.com/features/friday-review/music/success-so-special/article30768.ece |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} French hair-stylist Sandrin Veriar Seth designed two distinct hair-styles for the entire film and 13 hair-styles for the segment alone.{{Sfn|Dhananjayan|2011|page=293}} To avoid disruptions that could occur at the shooting spot due to Rajinikanth's fan following in [[Tamil Nadu]], [[Brinda (choreographer)|Brinda]] choreographed "Balleilakka", Rajinikanth's introduction song sequence in [[Wai, Maharashtra|Wai]], a [[hill station]] near [[Pune]] with 500 people for eight days. To add more colour to the sequence, a 50-member team of [[Puli Kali]] artists from [[Thrissur]] were employed by Shankar as background dancers.{{cite web |url=http://www.sify.com/movies/sivaji-song-in-pune-news-tamil-kkfvhKijdjbsi.html |title='Sivaji' song in Pune! |publisher=Sify |date=26 October 2006 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426070501/http://www.sify.com/movies/sivaji-song-in-pune-news-tamil-kkfvhKijdjbsi.html |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} In November 2006, sequences featuring Rajinkanth, Saran and Vivek were shot at the [[Pune Junction railway station]].{{cite web |url=http://www.behindwoods.com/tamil-movie-news/nov-06-02/06-11-06-sivaji.html |title=Scoop–Rajini's Sivaji Hospitals & Medical College |publisher=Behindwoods |date=6 November 2006 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426082541/http://www.behindwoods.com/tamil-movie-news/nov-06-02/06-11-06-sivaji.html |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} Filming of a key portion involving Rajinikanth and Vivek took place in the [[Victoria Public Hall]] building in [[Chennai]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-tamilnadu/refurbished-victoria-public-hall-likely-to-be-thrown-open-in-june/article2841679.ece |title=Refurbished Victoria Public Hall likely to be thrown open in June |work=The Hindu |date=29 January 2012 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |author=Deepa H. Ramakrishnan |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426075621/http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-tamilnadu/refurbished-victoria-public-hall-likely-to-be-thrown-open-in-june/article2841679.ece |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}}{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dAnV2D8UNcE |title=Sivaji The Boss Tamil (சிவாஜி) – Full Movie 1080p HD |publisher=AVM Productions |date=29 November 2013 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |medium=Motion picture |location=India |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150220012503/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dAnV2D8UNcE |archivedate=20 February 2015 |df=}} Clip from 1:58:30 to 2:01:45. A fight sequence and the song "Athiradi" were filmed at [[Binny and Co.|Binny Mills]]. The sets for the song were made bearing resemblance to the city of [[Venice]].{{cite web |title=Sivaji updates in Kumudam magazine |publisher=sivajimovie.blogspot.com |agency=[[Kumudam]] |url=http://sivajimovie.blogspot.com/2006/10/sivaji-updates-in-kumudam-magazine.html |date=29 October 2006 |accessdate=3 April 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426113832/http://sivajimovie.blogspot.com/2006/10/sivaji-updates-in-kumudam-magazine.html |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} For the climax scenes, which were filmed at the [[Magarpatta]] city SEZ towers, Rajinikanth tonsured his head.{{cite web |url=http://www.sify.com/movies/rajini-loses-his-hair-for-sivaji-news-tamil-kkfvgIgjgifsi.html |title=Rajini loses his hair for ''Sivaji'' |publisher=Sify |date=18 December 2006 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426083256/http://www.sify.com/movies/rajini-loses-his-hair-for-sivaji-news-tamil-kkfvgIgjgifsi.html |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}}{{cite web |url=http://www.behindwoods.com/features/Gallery/events/photos-2/sivaji-1/index.html |title=More pictures of Sivaji shooting |publisher=Behindwoods |accessdate=26 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426082536/http://www.behindwoods.com/features/Gallery/events/photos-2/sivaji-1/index.html |archivedate=26 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} The scenes where Sivaji gets the money he transferred to his friends by forgery were filmed in [[New York City]].{{cite AV media |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dAnV2D8UNcE |title=Sivaji The Boss Tamil (சிவாஜி) – Full Movie 1080p HD |publisher=AVM Productions |date=29 November 2013 |accessdate=26 April 2015 |medium=Motion picture |location=India |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150220012503/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dAnV2D8UNcE |archivedate=20 February 2015 |df=}} Clip from 2:03:25 to 2:05:35. The completion of those scenes in February 2007 marked the end of the principal photography.{{cite web |url=http://www.sify.com/movies/sivaji-shoot-complete-news-tamil-kkfveEbhjijsi.html |title='Sivaji' shoot complete! |publisher=Sify |date=16 February 2007 |accessdate=27 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150427013722/http://www.sify.com/movies/sivaji-shoot-complete-news-tamil-kkfveEbhjijsi.html |archivedate=27 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} The climactic fight between Sivaji and Adiseshan was filmed at [[Vels University]].{{cite web |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/tamil/movies/news/Colleges-turn-shooting-spots-in-Chennai/articleshow/47536976.cms |title=Colleges turn shooting spots in Chennai |work=The Times of India |date=4 June 2015 |accessdate=5 July 2015 |author=Nandita Ravi |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Znd23ueF?url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/tamil/movies/news/Colleges-turn-shooting-spots-in-Chennai/articleshow/47536976.cms |archivedate=5 July 2015 |deadurl=no |df=}} K. V. Anand told Shobha Warrier of [[Rediff.com|Rediff]] that the portions other than the songs and action sequences were completed in 65 days.{{cite web |url=http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/14sld6.htm |title=The man who shot ''Sivaji'' – Slide 6 |publisher=Rediff |author=Shobha Warrier |date=14 May 2007 |accessdate=25 April 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150427014200/http://specials.rediff.com/movies/2007/may/14sld6.htm |archivedate=27 April 2015 |deadurl=no}} For the film's dubbed Telugu version, Rajinikanth reshot some scenes.http://www.cinemaexpress.com/stories/columns/2018/may/20/viewfinder-the-big-bilingual-scam-6100.html == Themes and influences == Many critics stated that the theme of ''Sivaji'' has been inspired from Shankar's previous films ''[[Gentleman (1993 film)|Gentleman]]'' (1993) and ''[[Mudhalvan]]'' (1999).{{cite web |url=http://www.sify.com/movies/sivaji-review-tamil-14472632.html |title=Movie Review : Sivaji |work=Sify |accessdate=13 January 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140906081517/http://www.sify.com/movies/sivaji-review-tamil-14472632.html |archivedate=6 September 2014 |df=}} The film deals with the concept of corruption and money laundering and how the film's protagonist employs methods to get rid of those elements.{{cite web |url=http://www.upperstall.com/films/2007/sivaji-boss |title=Sivaji, The Boss |publisher=[[Upperstall.com]] |accessdate=13 January 2015 |author=Anand Subramanian |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141008170924/http://www.upperstall.com/films/2007/sivaji-boss |archivedate=8 October 2014}} Gopinath Rajendran of ''[[The New Indian Express]]'' compared the film's title character to [[Robin Hood]] for being a hero "who takes from the rich and passes it on to the poor".{{Cite news |url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/entertainment/tamil/2017/jun/21/heroes-from-the-west-1619370--1.html |title=Heroes from the West |last=Rajendran |first=Gopinath |date=22 June 2017 |work=[[The New Indian Express]] |access-date=28 July 2017}} Sivaji, who is a software engineer is frustrated with the corruption in India which is shown in the scene where he watches the pitiable condition of poor people stating that: "The rich get richer, the poor get poorer".{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/reel-city/article5055543.ece |title=Reel City |author=Sudhish Kamath |work=The Hindu |accessdate=13 January 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131202153041/http://www.thehindu.com/features/cinema/reel-city/article5055543.ece |archivedate=2 December 2013 |df=}} Sivaji's love for his country is also illustrated in a scene where he is advised by his uncle to go back to abroad but he says "Where else will I go? This is home."{{cite web |url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/chennai/chen-cinema/rajini-still-entertains-and-how/article4195634.ece |title=Rajini still entertains, and how! |author=SHIVAJI RAO |work=The Hindu |accessdate=13 January 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121216074223/http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/chennai/chen-cinema/rajini-still-entertains-and-how/article4195634.ece |archivedate=16 December 2012 |df=}} == Soundtrack == {{Main|Sivaji (soundtrack)}} After some re-recording of the background score in Paraguay,{{cite web |title=Background score for ''Sivaji'' mixed in London! |url=http://www.tamilstar.com/news/publish/article_3084.shtml |accessdate=12 April 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070717181616/http://www.tamilstar.com/news/publish/article_3084.shtml |archivedate=17 July 2007}} [[A.R. Rahman]] had been to London for additional re-recording.{{cite web |title=Audio raises expectations on Sivaji |url=http://www.indiaglitz.com/channels/tamil/article/30448.html |accessdate=12 April 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070415051156/http://www.indiaglitz.com/channels/tamil/article/30448.html |archivedate=15 April 2007 |df=}} A month and a half prior to the film's official soundtrack release, three songs from the soundtrack were leaked into the Internet. The songs, however, were only unofficial with low quality, where the official versions were composed slightly different and sung by different artists.{{cite web |url=http://www.indiaglitz.com/channels/tamil/article/30083.html |title=More info Sivaji songs available on net |publisher=Indiaglitz |date=23 March 2007 |accessdate=23 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111014211425/http://www.indiaglitz.com/channels/tamil/article/30083.html |archivedate=14 October 2011 |df=}}{{cite web |url=http://entertainment.oneindia.in/tamil/news/2007/shivaji-songs-020407.html |title=Shivaji songs available on the Internet |publisher=Oneindia |date=2 April 2007 |accessdate=23 June 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.behindwoods.com/tamil-movie-news/mar-07-04/26-03-07-rajini-kamal.html |title=shivaji superstar rajini sivaji movie gallery |publisher=Behindwoods |date=26 March 2007 |accessdate=23 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612065043/http://www.behindwoods.com/tamil-movie-news/mar-07-04/26-03-07-rajini-kamal.html |archivedate=12 June 2011 |df=}} == Release == The television rights of the film were sold to [[Kalaignar TV]] for {{INR}}40 million.{{cite web |url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2007/jun/19rajni.htm |title=Sivaji satellite rights |publisher=[[Rediff]] |date=19 June 2007 |accessdate=19 June 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070621153457/http://www.rediff.com/movies/2007/jun/19rajni.htm |archivedate=21 June 2007 |df=}} The film's distribution rights, as distributed by [[AVM Productions]] to various companies are {{INRConvert|35|m}} for the selling of rights to [[Kerala]], {{INRConvert|140|m}} for [[Andhra Pradesh]] and {{INRConvert|139.5|m}} for the rights to [[Ayngaran]], an international Tamil film distributor. The trailer was released by [[CNN-IBN]] on 30 May 2007 lasting for three minutes.{{cite news |url=http://www.ibnlive.com/videos/41628/exclusive-first-look-rajni-in-sivaji.html |title=Exclusive Trailer:Sivaji-The Boss |publisher=CNN-IBN |accessdate=30 May 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070531072320/http://www.ibnlive.com/videos/41628/exclusive-first-look-rajni-in-sivaji.html |archivedate=31 May 2007 |df=}} The official trailer was released by AVM to ''Galatta.com'', the official online sponsor and [[Ayngaran International]].{{cite news |url=http://www.ayngaran.com/Ayngaran/Ayngaran_Home.html?id=trailer&name=Shivaji |title=Sivaji: The Boss trailer! |publisher=[[Ayngaran International]] |accessdate=30 May 2007 |language=Tamil |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070602144702/http://www.ayngaran.com/Ayngaran/Ayngaran_Home.html?id=trailer&name=Shivaji |archivedate=2 June 2007 |df=}} The film was supposed to be released on the [[Tamil New Year]]'s day, 14 April 2007,{{cite news |title=`Sivaji' to be released on Tamil New Year's day |url=https://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-tamilnadu/%60Sivaji-to-be-released-on-Tamil-New-Years-day/article14724987.ece |accessdate=20 September 2018 |work=The Hindu |date=24 February 2007 |language=en-IN}}{{cite news |url=http://www.hindu.com/2007/04/29/stories/2007042916700200.htm |title=''Sivaji'' release likely to be delayed |accessdate=29 April 2007 |work=The Hindu |date=29 April 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070501073758/http://www.hindu.com/2007/04/29/stories/2007042916700200.htm |archivedate=1 May 2007 |df=}} but due to post-production delays, the film was released worldwide on 15 June 2007.{{cite news |url=http://www.hindu.com/2007/05/21/stories/2007052104560200.htm |title=''Sivaji'' release will be on June 16 |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=21 May 2007 |accessdate=10 July 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070624005000/http://www.hindu.com/2007/05/21/stories/2007052104560200.htm |archivedate=24 June 2007 |df=}}{{cite web |url=http://www.avm.in/movies.html |title=Movies from AVM Productions |publisher=[[AVM Productions]] |accessdate=6 June 2016 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160607080546/http://www.avm.in/movies.html |archivedate=7 June 2016}} On 15 July 2007, AVM Productions, the producers of the film, announced their decision to [[Dub localization|dub]] the film into [[Hindi language|Hindi]].{{cite news |url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/News/News_By_Industry/Media__Entertainment_/Entertainment/Sivaji_to_set_Hindi_heartland_on_fire/articleshow/2206139.cms |title=Sivaji to set Hindi heartland on fire |work=[[The Economic Times]] |date=15 July 2007 |accessdate=19 July 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070822212407/http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/News/News_By_Industry/Media__Entertainment_/Entertainment/Sivaji_to_set_Hindi_heartland_on_fire/articleshow/2206139.cms |archivedate=22 August 2007 |df=}}{{cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Regional/Sivaji-The-Boss-to-be-dubbed-in-Hindi/Article1-244964.aspx |title=Sivaji: The Boss to be dubbed in Hindi |work=Hindustan Times |date=28 August 2007 |accessdate=29 December 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131010144956/http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Regional/Sivaji-The-Boss-to-be-dubbed-in-Hindi/Article1-244964.aspx |archivedate=10 October 2013 |df=}} That version was released on 14 January 2010. M. Satyamoorthy, on 9 July 2007, sought to stop the film being screened, claiming that it defamed the [[Indian National Congress]], a political party, as well as its president, [[Sonia Gandhi]], and the then [[Prime Minister of India]], [[Manmohan Singh]]. Satyamoorthy cited a scene in which portraits of Gandhi and Singh are visible behind Adiseshan's chair, implying that Adiseshan was a member of the Indian National Congress.{{cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/StoryPage/StoryPage.aspx?id=0b4b27a2-c536-4c55-b69b-65dc7a320c06&ParentID=76e0cb41-ba06-4e36-a58d-300306debc72&&Headline=Rajnikant's+EMSivaji-the+boss+%2fEMcaught+in+a+political+wrangle |title=Rajnikant's Sivaji-the boss caught in a political wrangle |work=[[Hindustan Times]] |date=9 July 2007 |accessdate=17 July 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070819232942/http://www.hindustantimes.com/StoryPage/StoryPage.aspx?id=0b4b27a2-c536-4c55-b69b-65dc7a320c06&ParentID=76e0cb41-ba06-4e36-a58d-300306debc72&&Headline=Rajnikant's+EMSivaji-the+boss+%2FEMcaught+in+a+political+wrangle |archivedate=19 August 2007 }} Satyamoorthy also claimed {{INRConvert|500|m}} in damages from the film's producer, director and lead actor to be paid to the [[Tamil Nadu]] section of the party.{{cite news |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2007-07-09/india/27995808_1_villain-sivaji-rajnikant |title=PIL seeking ban on Sivaji-the Boss filed in Madras HC |work=[[The Times of India]]}} Jaya Rajadevan, one of the film's assistant directors, sought an [[injunction]] in civil court to stop screening of the film for alleged plagiarism. Rajadevan claimed that he had written the film's story and had discussed it with Shankar's manager in 2005.{{Sfn|Dhananjayan|2014|page=462}} Although the court sent notices to Shankar, among others, the screening of the film was not stopped.{{Sfn|Dhananjayan|2011|page=293-294}} === Special screenings === Rajinikanth used his political affiliations to screen the film for several politicians. He went to [[Hyderabad, India|Hyderabad]] to showcase the film for the former [[Andhra Pradesh]] [[Chief Minister]], [[Chandrababu Naidu]], on 14 June 2007.{{cite web |url=http://www.ibnlive.com/news/naidu-calls-rajini-to-join-third-front/42931-4.html |title=Naidu calls Rajini to join Third Front |publisher=[[CNN-IBN]] |date=15 June 2007 |accessdate=14 July 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070709061321/http://www.ibnlive.com/news/naidu-calls-rajini-to-join-third-front/42931-4.html |archivedate=9 July 2007 |df=}} At the screening, Rajinikanth told the media that he would invite the Chief Minister, [[Rajasekhara Reddy]], for a special viewing as well. Rajinikanth said that he had screened the film to current and former [[Tamil Nadu]] Chief Ministers, Dr. [[Karunanidhi]]{{cite news |url=http://www.hindu.com/2007/06/15/stories/2007061502500600.htm |title=Rajnikanth welcome to join Third Front: Naidu |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=15 June 2007 |accessdate=14 July 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070618192545/http://www.hindu.com/2007/06/15/stories/2007061502500600.htm |archivedate=18 June 2007 |df=}} and [[J. Jayalalithaa|Jayalalitha]],{{cite web |url=http://www.zeenews.com/Entertainment/Movies-Theatre/2007-06-15/377080news.html |title=Sivaji hits screens; Rajni fans throng theatres |publisher=[[Zee Network]] |date=15 June 2007 |accessdate=14 July 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211020742/http://www.zeenews.com/Entertainment/Movies-Theatre/2007-06-15/377080news.html |archivedate=11 December 2008 |deadurl=unfit}} respectively, and that India's [[Finance Minister]], [[P Chidambaram]], was also keen to watch the film. A private screening was also shown to [[Amitabh Bachchan]].{{cite web |url=http://www.timesnow.tv/Rajni_meets_Amitabh/articleshow/2154964.cms |title=Rajni meets Amitabh |publisher=Times Now. TV |date=27 June 2007 |accessdate=14 July 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070630182826/http://www.timesnow.tv/Rajni_meets_Amitabh/articleshow/2154964.cms |archivedate=30 June 2007 |df=}} === 3D re-release === A 2012 re-release, also known as ''Sivaji 3D,'' was created by [[Master recording|re-mastering]] the original to [[Dolby Atmos]] and [[2D to 3D conversion|post-converting]] to [[3D film|3D]] format and cutting half an hour of running time.{{cite news |url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/sivaji-3d-movie-review/1/236990.html |title=Sivaji 3D: Rajinism just got bigger |work=India Today |date=10 December 2012 |agency=Indo-Asian News Service |accessdate=23 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029203739/http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/sivaji-3d-movie-review/1/236990.html |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df=}} ''Sivaji 3D'' is the first Indian film to be launched with the new Dolby Atmos platform.{{Sfn|Dhananjayan|2014|page=462}}{{cite web |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/rajinikanth-starrer-sivaji-3d-will-be-indias-first-to-release-with-dolby-atmos/308756-71-180.html |title=Rajinikanth starrer 'Sivaji 3D' will be India's first to release with Dolby Atmos |publisher=CNN IBN |date=4 December 2012 |accessdate=23 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206093725/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/rajinikanth-starrer-sivaji-3d-will-be-indias-first-to-release-with-dolby-atmos/308756-71-180.html |archivedate=6 December 2013 |df=}} The trailer of 3D version was launched on 13 August 2012 at [[Prasad Studios|Prasad Labs]] along with Rajinikanth.{{cite web |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/photogallery/7170.html |title=In pics: Rajinikanth unveils 'Sivaji 3D' trailer |publisher=CNN IBN |date=14 August 2012 |accessdate=23 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206105306/http://ibnlive.in.com/photogallery/7170.html |archivedate=6 December 2013 |df=}} The 3D version released on 12 December 2012, coinciding with Rajinikanth's birthday.{{Sfn|Dhananjayan|2014|page=462}}{{cite web |url=http://ibnlive.in.com/news/121212-rajinikanth-will-mark-his-62nd-birthday-with-sivaji-3d/309147-71-180.html |title=12.12.12: Rajinikanth will mark his 62nd birthday with 'Sivaji 3D' |publisher=CNN IBN |date=6 December 2012 |accessdate=23 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206105302/http://ibnlive.in.com/news/121212-rajinikanth-will-mark-his-62nd-birthday-with-sivaji-3d/309147-71-180.html |archivedate=6 December 2013 |df=}} The runtime of 3D version was shorter than original, cut to two hours and thirty-five minutes.{{cite web |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/tamil/movie-reviews/Sivaji-3D/movie-review/17728504.cms |title=Sivaji 3D Movie Review |work=The Times of India |date=14 December 2012 |accessdate=4 November 2016 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20161104111557/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/tamil/movie-reviews/Sivaji-3D/movie-review/17728504.cms |archivedate=4 November 2016 |deadurl=no |df=}} == Box office == The theatrical rights of the film were sold for {{INRConvert|26|m}}{{cite web |url=http://www.hindu.com/2007/03/13/stories/2007031304690400.htm |title='Sivaji' producers clarify on sale of theatrical rights |work=The Hindu |accessdate=13 January 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029191235/http://www.hindu.com/2007/03/13/stories/2007031304690400.htm |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df=}} in Kerala and {{INRConvert|80|m}} in Andhra Pradesh. Worldwide, the film was estimated to have been released in about 750 screens.{{cite web |url=http://www.businessstandard.com/india/news/heroworshipping-rajinikanth/287889/ |title=Heroworshipping Rajinikanth |first=Kishore |last=Singh |date=16 June 2007 |accessdate=9 August 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001123837/http://www.businessstandard.com/india/news/heroworshipping-rajinikanth/287889/ |archivedate=1 October 2011 |df=}} The film opened to virtually full cinemas.{{cite web |url=http://www.ibnlive.com/news/filmy-fiscal-rajinis-sivaji-rules-bo/43170-8.html |title=Filmy Fiscal: Rajini's Sivaji rules BO |publisher=[[CNN-IBN]] |date=19 June 2007 |accessdate=11 July 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070912003446/http://www.ibnlive.com/news/filmy-fiscal-rajinis-sivaji-rules-bo/43170-8.html |archivedate=12 September 2007 |df=}} ''Sivaji'' was released in 303 screens in Tamil Nadu, 300 screens in Andhra Pradesh; 12 screens in North India and 145 screens across the rest of the world.{{cite web |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2010-07-29/news-interviews/28302401_1_films-distributors-and-exhibitors-telugu-stars |title=Dubbed films bounce back |work=The Times of India |date=29 July 2010 |quote=buyers lost nearly {{INR}} 40 million by procuring Sivaji for {{INR}} 160 million, as it failed to impress beyond the Nizam region}} It was released in 16 screens in [[Chennai]] and grossed {{INRConvert|13.5|m}} within the first four days, at that point a new record for [[Tamil films|Tamil]] cinema. The film also debuted well in [[Kerala]] and in [[Bangalore]]. Despite protests from pro-[[Kannada]] groups, the film debuted in 13 screens.{{cite web |url=http://www.screenindia.com/fullstory.php?content_id=16189 |title=Sivaji cuts across language barrier |work=[[The Indian Express]] |first=Roshmila |last=Bhattacharya |date=22 June 2007 |accessdate=11 July 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070626041920/http://www.screenindia.com/fullstory.php?content_id=16189 |archivedate=26 June 2007 |df=}} In the national capital, New Delhi, the film debuted on 4 screens in [[PVR Cinemas]].{{cite web |url=http://www.ibnlive.com/news/sivaji-sweeps-delhi/43024-8.html?xml |title=Sivaji takes Delhi by storm |publisher=[[CNN-IBN]] |date=16 June 2007 |accessdate=10 July 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070703155628/http://www.ibnlive.com/news/sivaji-sweeps-delhi/43024-8.html?xml |archivedate=3 July 2007 |df=}} Based on what the distributors claim, there was "overwhelming response to the film", with the number of screens increasing to 12 by the second week.{{cite web |url=http://www.zeenews.com/articles.asp?aid=378909&sid=ENT&ssid=1 |title=Rajni rocks as ''Sivaji'' rules in Delhi too! |publisher=[[Zee Entertainment Enterprises|Zee]] |date=23 June 2007 |accessdate=11 July 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070626173516/http://www.zeenews.com/articles.asp?aid=378909&sid=ENT&ssid=1 |archivedate=26 June 2007 |df=}} The film made a good debut in the nation's other metros as well such as [[Mumbai]] and [[Kolkata]],{{cite web |url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1070620/asp/calcutta/story_7946087.asp |title=The Boss breaks the plex barrier – After Southern storm, Rajanikanth mega movie is Friday's biggest release |first=Priyanka |last=Roy |date=20 June 2007 |accessdate=11 July 2007 |work=The Telegraph |location=Kolkota |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070625201430/http://www.telegraphindia.com/1070620/asp/calcutta/story_7946087.asp |archivedate=25 June 2007 |df=}} as well as in other non-traditional markets for Tamil films such as Pune{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Cities/Sivaji_opens_to_packed_houses/rssarticleshow/2143355.cms |title=Sivaji opens to packed houses |work=[[The Times of India]] |date=23 June 2007 |accessdate=11 July 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070706123547/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/Cities/Sivaji_opens_to_packed_houses/rssarticleshow/2143355.cms |archivedate=6 July 2007 |df=}} and Baroda.{{cite web |url=http://cities.expressindia.com/fullstory.php?newsid=244854 |title=Rajni Roars |work=[[The Indian Express]] |author=Apurva |date=7 July 2007 |accessdate=11 July 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012184008/http://cities.expressindia.com/fullstory.php?newsid=244854 |archivedate=12 October 2007 |df=}} The film grossed {{INR}} 40.7 million{{cite web |url=http://behindwoods.com/tamil-movies-slide-shows/movie-1/top-ten-movies/tamil-cinema-topten-movies.html |title=tamil box office collections Tamil top ten films top 10 movies sivaji rajinikanth shankar avm shriya picture gallery images |publisher= |accessdate=13 January 2015 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070708072634/http://behindwoods.com/tamil-movies-slide-shows/movie-1/top-ten-movies/tamil-cinema-topten-movies.html |archivedate=8 July 2007}} in two weeks; {{INR}} 85 million in five weeks,{{cite web |url=http://www.naachgaana.com/2007/07/23/chennai-box-office-battle-sivaji-or-kireedom/ |title=Chennai Box office battle: Sivaji or Kireedom? |publisher= |accessdate=13 January 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113164705/http://www.naachgaana.com/2007/07/23/chennai-box-office-battle-sivaji-or-kireedom/ |archivedate=13 January 2015 |df=}} and {{INR}} 100 million in seven weeks in Chennai.{{cite web |url=http://entertainment.oneindia.in/tamil/news/2007/shivaji-50-days-010807.html |title=Shivaji still rules BO after 50 days |work=www.filmibeat.com |accessdate=13 January 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029183757/http://entertainment.oneindia.in/tamil/news/2007/shivaji-50-days-010807.html |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df=}} ''Sivaji'' was also successful in international markets. The film had a wide release with over 145 prints and in 200 theatres (Tamil Version alone) in over 20 countries across South East Asia, Europe, North America, GCC and Australia and others, one of the widest release for an Indian film in the international markets. Internationally, ''Sivaji'' had good screenings in Malaysia.{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200706/s1953351.htm |title=Movie-goers riot over film hitches |publisher=ABC News |date=17 June 2007 |accessdate=25 December 2007 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081210173608/http://www.abc.net.au/news/newsitems/200706/s1953351.htm |archivedate=10 December 2008}}{{cite news |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2007/06/16/idUSKLR65626 |agency=Reuters |title=Malaysian fans enraged by Indian film delay -paper |date=16 June 2007 |accessdate=9 August 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029201624/https://www.reuters.com/article/2007/06/16/idUSKLR65626 |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df=}} grossing over US$2 million in Malaysia,{{cite web |url=http://www.screendaily.com/malaysian-box-office-hits-all-time-high-of-100m/4037013.article |title=Malaysian box office hits all-time high of $100m |publisher= |accessdate=13 January 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141204202539/http://www.screendaily.com/malaysian-box-office-hits-all-time-high-of-100m/4037013.article |archivedate=4 December 2014 |df=}} ''Sivaji'' made a debut with 150 shows in Singapore.{{cite web |url=http://timesnow.tv/articleshow/2132948.cms |title=''Sivaji'' is the boss in Singapore |work=TimesNow |first=Jennifer |last=Marostica |date=19 June 2007 |accessdate=10 July 2007 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070706103214/http://timesnow.tv/articleshow/2132948.cms |archivedate=6 July 2007}} In Sri Lanka, the film debuted across 70 screens with all 700 shows virtually sold out.{{cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/StoryPage/StoryPage.aspx?id=14dcab9d-0da6-4414-9543-acf801f8820b&MatchID1=4479&TeamID1=6&TeamID2=25&MatchType1=2&SeriesID1=1115&PrimaryID=4479&Headline=EMSivaji+%2fEMtakes+Sri+Lanka+by+storm |title=Sivaji takes Sri Lanka by storm |work=[[Hindustan Times]] |first=PK |last=Balachandran |date=22 June 2007 |accessdate=11 July 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930031641/http://www.hindustantimes.com/StoryPage/StoryPage.aspx?id=14dcab9d-0da6-4414-9543-acf801f8820b&MatchID1=4479&TeamID1=6&TeamID2=25&MatchType1=2&SeriesID1=1115&PrimaryID=4479&Headline=EMSivaji+%2fEMtakes+Sri+Lanka+by+storm |archivedate=30 September 2007 }} In the [[Persian Gulf]] that contains a sizeably large Indian diaspora, the film opened to a good response.{{cite news |url=http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/009200706181231.htm |title=1,000 labourers to watch ''Sivaji'' free in Dubai |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=18 June 2007 |accessdate=11 July 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930200852/http://www.hindu.com/thehindu/holnus/009200706181231.htm |archivedate=30 September 2007 |df=}} The film has collected over $8.5 Million from the overseas markets. In Canada, the film released in 10 screens in 3 major cities along with special screenings for the Tamil diaspora in the smaller cities.{{cite web |url=http://entertainment.oneindia.in/tamil/exclusive/shivaji-overseas-200607.html |title=Shivaji storms the world |publisher=One India |last=Settu |first=Shankar |date=20 June 2007 |accessdate=8 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120709140835/http://entertainment.oneindia.in/tamil/exclusive/shivaji-overseas-200607.html |archivedate=9 July 2012 }} In United Kingdom, the film debuted on the box-office list at No.9 with earnings of about £14,000 per screen and was the first Tamil film to enter UK Top 10. In United States, ''Sivaji'' was released in 24 screens with subsequent additions of 19 and 21 screens for the Tamil version and Telugu version respectively.{{cite web |url=http://news.moneycontrol.com/mccode/news/article/news_article.php?autono=286784 |title=''Sivaji'' is all set to be a hit in US |publisher=Moneycontrol.com |date=15 June 2007 |accessdate=11 July 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070617171150/http://news.moneycontrol.com/mccode/news/article/news_article.php?autono=286784 |archivedate=17 June 2007}} The producers of the film claimed that the film was going to be dubbed in Chinese and Japanese by [[Ayngaran International]], the holder of international rights of the film. The response in [[Cape Town]] was disappointing, while the box-office collections in [[Johannesburg]] and Durban allowed it to become the first Tamil film to feature in the South African box-office top 10.{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/intl/southafrica/?yr=2007&wk=32&p=.htm |title=South Africa (Entire Region) Box Office, August 10–12, 2007 |publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]] |date=12 August 2007 |accessdate=22 November 2007 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071024011728/http://www.boxofficemojo.com/intl/southafrica/?yr=2007&wk=32&p=.htm |archivedate=24 October 2007 |df=}} [[Singapore Airlines]] bought a 3-month exclusive in-flight screening rights to the film, a first for the airline for any Tamil film.{{cite web |url=http://www.thetimes.co.za/PrintEdition/News/Article.aspx?id=653801 |title=The Big B hits back at criticism by Aamir Khan |publisher=The Times, South Africa |date=8 December 2007 |accessdate=8 January 2008 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081211044332/http://www.thetimes.co.za/PrintEdition/News/Article.aspx?id=653801 |archivedate=11 December 2008}} In the UK, 13 seconds of the film was cut.{{cite web |url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/website/Classified.nsf/0/6B6190B9DA3DEE64802572F700492C67?OpenDocument |title=Sivaji – The Boss |publisher=bbfc.co.uk |accessdate=9 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090112110135/http://www.bbfc.co.uk/website/Classified.nsf/0/6B6190B9DA3DEE64802572F700492C67?OpenDocument |archivedate=12 January 2009 |df=}} The original film showed Rajinikanth throwing a firecracker into his mouth, lighting it and then spitting it out at Pattimanram Raja, which was removed to give the film a 12A rating, The Ayngaran UK DVD release was uncut and given an 18 rating by the [[BBFC]]. It was also the first Tamil film to be officially released on a [[1080p]] High Definition [[Blu-ray]] disc.{{cite web |url=http://www.ayngaran.com/bluray.php |title=Sivaji – Blu-ray details |publisher=ayngaran.com |accessdate=9 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110818172154/http://www.ayngaran.com/bluray.php |archivedate=18 August 2011 |df=}} The overseas distributor Ayngaran International reported collections as follows: US$2,000,000, Canada $500,000, UK$750,000, Europe and Gulf $750,000, Malaysia $2,000,000, Singapore $750,000, Sri Lanka $1,250,000, Australia, New Zealand & Thailand $250,000.{{cite web |url=http://www.behindwoods.com/tamil-movie-news/july-07-02/13-07-07-sivaji.html |title=Sivaji makes whopping 400% profit overseas |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102060733/http://www.behindwoods.com/tamil-movie-news/july-07-02/13-07-07-sivaji.html |archivedate=2 November 2013 |df=}} ''Sivaji'' was released in South Africa in late July 2007 after six weeks of its release by the leading South African distributor Ster Kinekor with four prints and released in Johannesburg, Cape Town and Durban.{{cite web |url=http://www.mediaupdate.co.za/?IDStory=5714 |title=SIVAJI – The box-office Boss |date=13 November 2007 |accessdate=1 February 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150114104859/http://www.mediaupdate.co.za/?IDStory=5714 |archivedate=14 January 2015 |df=}}{{cite web |url=http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/intl/?page=&country=ZA&id=_fUNENGANODELUJO01 |title=Sivaji (2007) |accessdate=1 February 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102170700/http://boxofficemojo.com/movies/intl/?page=&country=ZA&id=_fUNENGANODELUJO01 |archivedate=2 November 2013 |df=}} == Reception == === Critical response === Malathi Rangarajan of ''[[The Hindu]]'', in a review about the story, said that the lead character carrying out a rebellion against corruption was something "not be true to life". She concluded by saying that "the story sags towards the end". She, however, appreciated the performances of the prominent actors, the soundtrack, art direction, photography and the animation.{{cite web |url=http://www.hindu.com/fr/2007/06/22/stories/2007062250530200.htm |title=A magnum opus in style – Sivaji |work=The Hindu |date=22 June 2007 |accessdate=8 January 2008 |author=Malathi Rangarajan |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071010091847/http://www.hindu.com/fr/2007/06/22/stories/2007062250530200.htm |archivedate=10 October 2007 |df=}} Ananth Krishnan, another review from ''The Hindu'', a month after the film's release, said that the film "... presents an effective diagnosis of entrenched corruption but the rather disturbing remedy it offers is, good old vigilantism." It concluded by saying that, though the film did well at the box-office, the message of rejecting the corrupt system instead of reforming it was troubling.{{cite news |url=http://www.hindu.com/2007/07/15/stories/2007071555071000.htm |title=Sivaji: super hit but the message is troubling |work=The Hindu |date=15 July 2007 |accessdate=9 January 2008 |author=Ananth Krishnan |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118172127/http://www.hindu.com/2007/07/15/stories/2007071555071000.htm |archivedate=18 January 2008 |df=}} T. S. V. Hari of ''[[Hindustan Times]]'' said that the director, Shankar, was not creative enough for the film and added this by saying "''Sivaji'' turns out to be a rehash of all his previous jingoistic claptrap efforts". It appreciated the other technical departments and suggested a good response at the box office.{{cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Reviews/REVIEW-Sivaji-the-Boss/Article1-230429.aspx |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130125060544/http://www.hindustantimes.com/Entertainment/Reviews/REVIEW-Sivaji-the-Boss/Article1-230429.aspx |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 January 2013 |title=REVIEW: Sivaji: the Boss |work=Hindustan Times |date=16 June 2007 |accessdate=8 January 2008 |author=TSV Hari}} ''[[The Times of India]]'' had a similar review about the story saying that "it had nothing new to offer" but promised it to be entertaining and gave it four stars.{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/regional/tamil/movie-reviews/Sivaji-The-Boss/movie-review/2142960.cms |title=Sivaji The Boss |work=The Times of India |date=23 June 2007 |accessdate=8 January 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121103224310/http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/regional/tamil/movie-reviews/Sivaji-The-Boss/movie-review/2142960.cms |archivedate=3 November 2012 |df=}} R G Vijayasarathy of [[Rediff.com]] summed the film by saying, "No logic, only Rajni's magic". About the story, he said, "Unfortunately, (the) message is lost in the maze of illogical and sometimes absurd sequences". The review, however, praised the performances of Rajinikanth, Shriya and Vivek and the technical crew.{{cite web |url=http://www.rediff.com/movies/2007/jun/15sivaji2.htm |title=No logic, only Rajni's magic |publisher=Rediff |last=Vijayasarathy |first=R. G. |date=15 June 2007 |accessdate=9 January 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080102150318/http://www.rediff.com/movies/2007/jun/15sivaji2.htm |archivedate=2 January 2008 |df=}} [[Sify]] wrote: "There is only one hero here, [..] – Rajni himself. Such is the overpowering screen presence of his cinematic charisma in every frame of the film. The film works big time as Shankar has made the film on a grand scale, [..] which is a visual treat with superbly choreographed action scenes. All this comes with top-of-the line techno-finesse, perhaps the best ever in Tamil cinema" and also wrote that "Technically, [..] a revelation [..] there are stunning visuals, which is paisa vasool. K.V.Anand's cinematography is top class. Art director Thotta Tharani work is enticing, especially the sets in songs". === Accolades === ;2008 [[National Film Awards]]{{cite web |url=http://dff.nic.in/2011/55th_nff_2007.pdf |title=55th National Film Awards (PDF) |publisher=[[Directorate of Film Festivals]] |accessdate=26 March 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131029192455/http://dff.nic.in/2011/55th_nff_2007.pdf |archivedate=29 October 2013 |df=}} * Won – [[National Film Award for Best Special Effects|Silver Lotus Award for Best Special Effects]] – M.S. Indian Artists, Chennai ;2008 [[Filmfare Awards South]][http://bollyspice.com/6215/happy-days-at-the-55th-tiger-balm-filmfare-south-awards 55th Filmfare Awards South] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402090238/http://bollyspice.com/6215/happy-days-at-the-55th-tiger-balm-filmfare-south-awards |date= 2 April 2015 }}. Bollyspice.com. * Won – [[Filmfare Best Music Director Award (Tamil)|Filmfare Award for Best Music Director]] – [[A.R. Rahman]] * Won – [[Filmfare Best Cinematographer Award (South)|Filmfare Award for Best Cinematographer]] – [[K. V. Anand]] * Won – [[Filmfare Best Art Director Award (South)|Filmfare Best Art Director Award]] – [[Thotta Tharani]] * Nominated – [[Filmfare Best Actor Award (Tamil)|Filmfare Award for Best Actor]] – [[Rajinikanth]] * Nominated – [[Filmfare Best Film Award (Tamil)|Filmfare Award for Best Film]] – ''Sivaji'' * Nominated – [[Filmfare Best Female Playback Award (Tamil)|Filmfare Award for Best Playback Singer Female]] – [[Chinmayi]] ;2007 [[Vijay Awards]][https://web.archive.org/web/20080726022319/http://www.starboxoffice.com/kollywood/vijayawards/about.html Vijay Awards].Star Box Office. * Won – [[Vijay Award for Favourite Hero]] – [[Rajinikanth]] * Nominated – [[Vijay Award for Favourite Heroine]] – [[Shriya Saran]] * Won – [[Vijay Award for Best Music Director]] – [[A.R. Rahman]] * Nominated – [[Vijay Award for Best Female Playback Singer|Best Playback Singer Female]] – [[Chinmayi]]{{cite web |author=Chinmayee |url=http://chinmayisripada.blogspot.com/2008/05/vijay-awards-2007.html |title=WhatToNameIt: Vijay Awards 2007 |publisher=Chinmayisripada.blogspot.com |date=3 May 2008 |accessdate=23 June 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111011001315/http://chinmayisripada.blogspot.com/2008/05/vijay-awards-2007.html |archivedate=11 October 2011 |df=}} * Nominated – [[Vijay Award for Best Male Playback Singer|Best Playback Singer Male]] – [[Udit Narayan]] 2007 [[Tamil Nadu State Film Awards]] {{cite news |url=http://www.hindu.com/2009/09/29/stories/2009092950250100.htm |title=Rajini, Kamal win best actor awards |work=[[The Hindu]] |accessdate=28 September 2009 |location=Chennai, India |date=29 September 2009}} *Won- [[Tamil Nadu State Film Award for Best Film]] – First Prize == Notes == {{notelist}} == References == {{Reflist}} == Sources == * {{cite book |last=Dhananjayan |first=G. |authorlink=G. Dhananjayan |title=The Best of Tamil Cinema, 1931 to 2010: 1977–2010 |year=2011 |volume=2 |publisher=Galatta Media |isbn=978-81-921043-0-0 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Dhananjayan |first=G. |title=Pride of Tamil Cinema: 1931 to 2013 |date=2014 |publisher=Blue Ocean Publishers |url=https://books.google.co.in/books?id=e07vBwAAQBAJ |isbn=978-93-84301-05-7 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |last=Ramachandran |first=Naman |title=Rajinikanth: The Definitive Biography |titlelink=Rajinikanth: The Definitive Biography |year=2014 |origyear=2012 |edition=2nd |publisher=[[Penguin Books]] |location=New Delhi |isbn=978-81-8475-796-5 |ref=harv}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|0479751|Sivaji}} * {{Allrovi movie|393508|Sivaji}} {{S. revision.text:
{{redirect|Star boy|other uses|Starboy (disambiguation)}} [[Image:Sternsinger aus Hochfranken.JPG|thumb|300px|<center>Star singers from [[Hochfranken]].</center>]] [[Image:Stamp of Moldova 341.gif|thumb|<center>Star boys. Children singing Christmas carols.</center>]]
'''Star singers''' also known as '''Epiphany singers''', or '''Star boys' singing procession''' (England), are children and young people walking from house to house with a star on a rod and often wearing crowns and dressed in clothes to resemble the [[Biblical Magi|Three Magi]] (variously also known as Three Kings or Three Wise Man). The singing processions have their roots in an old medieval ecclesiastical play, centred on the Biblical Magi of the Christmas story in the [[Gospel of Matthew]] (Mt 2,1-28), appropriate to [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]]. It is observed usually during the period between 27 December and 6 January (the feast of the Epiphany).
In Scandinavia and Central Europe a special set of songs, distinct from Christmas carols has developed in this context. In England, the liturgical drama developed from being performed by cathedral schoolboys in the 16th century to become a more secular mystery drama, containing also some ordinary Christmas songs and carols. Historically performed by boys and male adolescents only, it is nowadays performed by children and young people of both sexes in most regions where the tradition is alive. [[File:01 Das katholische Fest der Heiligen drei Könige 2013 in Sanok.JPG|thumb|300px|<center>Star boys and angels singing carols in church during [[Christmas]] and Epiphany in [[Sanok]], Poland 2013</center>]]
== History == At a synod in [[Konstanz]] in Germany at Christmas in 1417 the British clergies performed the Star boy drama for the rest of the participants at the meeting. They wore expensive costumes and had a large shining star.<ref>Alv S. Hvidbergskaar: May the star come in? [Manuscript from a speech in the Norwegian Radio NRK on 3. January 1953], p. 6-7, op. cit. in Edvardsen 1993, p. 109.</ref> The performance was a huge success at the church conference and could have been one of the main reasons for growing popularity of the drama in post-medieval Europe.
The importance of the Twelfth Day and the feast of the Epiphany grew with the introduction of the Gregorian calendar as the day, according to the earlier Julian calendar, is also the Old Christmas Day.
After the [[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]] in the 16th century, pupils of the cathedral schools in Protestant nations conducted these processions to raise funds to replace the church support that had disappeared. The custom passed further on to the general populace as a kind of narrative folk drama, but seems to have declined in its original form since the late 19th century.
Since then the singing procession has become common in many parts of Europe (both in Catholic and Protestant areas) and in Russia. In most countries it is no longer restricted to boys, but children or both sexes participate. In Germany, Austria and Belgium organisations centrally organise the processions, collecting money for charity or international aid projects, leading to a widespread support of the custom.
[[File:Пимоненко Колядки 1880.jpg|thumbnail|<center>In Russia. 1880</center>]]
== Central Europe == [[Image:Bundesarchiv B 145 Bild-F064527-0021, Bundespräsident empfängt Sternsinger.jpg|thumb|left|300px|<center>Epiphany singers are received by Germany's Federal President [[Karl Carstens]] in Bonn 1 December 1982. The poster reads: "Dreikönigssingen 1983 AMANI. Damit Kinder heute leben können".</center>]] {{clear}} In Germany, the Czech Republic and Austria the Epiphany singing is performed at or close to Epiphany (January 6) and has developed into a nationwide custom, where the children of both sexes call on every door and are given sweets and money for charity projects - mostly in aid of poorer children in other countries.<ref>http://www.americancatholic.org/Messenger/Dec2000/Feature1.asp</ref>
A tradition in most of Central Europe involves writing a blessing above the main door of the home. For instance if the year is 2014, it would be "20 * C + M + B + 14". The initials refer to the Latin phrase "Christus mansionem benedicat" (= May Christ bless this house<!--mansionem=house, apartment; benedicat=he bless-->); folkloristically the letters are often interpreted as the names of the Three Wise Men (Caspar, Melchior, Balthasar). In Catholic parts of Germany and in Austria, this is done by the ''Sternsinger'' (literally "Star singers"). After having sung their songs, recited a poem, and collected donations for children in poorer parts of the world, they will chalk the blessing on the top of the door frame or place a sticker with the blessing.
=== In Germany === Annually around 300 000 people are active in collecting donations in Germany.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sternsinger.de/|title=Home - Die Sternsinger|last=Sternsinger|website=Die Sternsinger|language=de-DE|access-date=2017-01-25}}</ref>
=== In Austria === In Austria the biggest carol singing campaign is organized by the "DKA" (Dreikönigsaktion), an aid foundation founded by the youth organization [[Katholische Jungschar]]. Annually about 85,000 children and 30,000 adults take part in the "Dreikönigsaktion".<ref>[https://www.dka.at/english/about-us/ Homepage of DKA: About us]</ref>
[[Image:Sternsinger.jpg|thumb||300px|Star singers in [[Vienna]], Austria.]]
=== In Slovakia === The biggest carol singing campaign in Slovakia is Dobrá Novina (English: "Good News"). It is also one of the biggest charity campaigns by young people in the country. Dobrá Novina is organized by the youth organization [[ERko – Hnutie kresťanských spoločenstiev detí|eRko]].<ref>cf. also Jančovič, J, Fialová, Z and O’Mullane, M (2015) '[http://www.developmenteducationreview.com/issue20-perspectives%205 Development Education at University Level in Slovakia: Experiences and Challenges]', Vol. 20, Spring, pp. 166-185.</ref>
== England and Scotland == {{main|Chalking the door}} The Star singers, aged about ten to fifteen, are dressed in long white shirts and pointed brown or white paper hats, in imitation of a well-known picture of the Biblical Magi as [[Babylon]]ians Balthazar carries the star and Caspar and Melchior are armed with wooden swords. The other characters usually do not disguise themselves but also dress in long shirts, often in brown, green or grey colours and conical hats. Joseph has got a cylindrical paper hat and a wooden timber or broad axe. King Herod wears a crown and he and his soldiers carry wooden swords.<ref>Neither the star play nor the costumes have however anything to do with the [[Plough Monday]] [[Mummers Play|mummers]] in England as suggested by Kathleen Stokker 2000, p. 109.</ref> In the crowd there may also be shepherds with long shirts and sticks and some angels with white shirts and wings.
The Star singers walk about from house to house "singing at the doors, with a star on a pole".<ref>Laurits Bødker 1965, p. 288.</ref> The dramatic part is introduced by one of the Wise Men knocking on someone's door asking: "May the star come in?" If the offer is accepted, they are all invited inside. Then the whole procession will enter the home singing a special Christmas carol. Then the play begins.
In the performance, the [[Biblical Magi|Three Wise Men]], [[Biblical Magi#Names|Gaspar]], [[Melchior]] and [[Biblical Magi#Names|Balthazar]], are first confronted by [[Saint Joseph|Joseph]], who tries to protect the newborn baby [[Jesus]] (a doll) and his wife [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Mary]] from the intruders with a wooden axe. The three magi are however most welcome inside after saying that they have brought with them presents for the child. The Wise Men also have to mislead [[Herod the Great|King Herod]], who is also trying to find the new born 'prince' in the stable. Both Gaspar and Melchior fight the king and his men with swords, together with Joseph who uses his broad axe, while Mary nurses her son and Balthazar takes care of the shining star.
After the performance [[Judas Iscariot|Judas]] comes to collect money or other gifts from the audience in a large bag. The boys and girls are usually treated to drinks and cakes afterwards. Then the Star singers leave the house for their next visit to somewhere in the neighbourhood, singing a song containing a farewell and many thanks for the received gifts.
The star itself is made anew each year, using transparent paper on a constructed frame built of wooden lists and with one to three candles placed inside. The star on the rod has to be movable and turned around all the time, so that the paper does not get overheated and does not go up in flame.
The Star boys' singing procession in England seems later to have been mixed together with several other kinds of carol singers at Christmas. They do not go from house to house, but visit two or three local pubs to receive free beer. Nowadays they are not carrying the shining star anymore, but just a quadrangular paraffin wax on a long stick or even a candle lamp with an ordinary handle.<ref>Edvardsen 1993, p. 109-110. Refers to oral information collected from British theatre director [[Nadine Baylis]], in Haddenham ([[Buckinghamshire]]), and from Tove Gaarder, who grew up in the mining town [[Sunderland, Tyne and Wear|Sunderland]].</ref> Whereas religious folk plays are the norm in the rest of Europe, the British folk drama is absolutely secular, even if they are mostly taking place on the Christian festival days.
== "Stjernespill" in Scandinavia and Finland == [[Image:Tiernapojat oulussa.jpg|thumb|right|300px|<center>Finnish Star boys (''tiernapojat'') in [[Oulu]], 1919.</center>]] In the Nordic countries the Star boys' singing procession is known all along the coast, though not often in inland communities. At the end of the 1880s many objected to this Catholic form of organised begging, and officials began forbidding the practice. By the 1900s it had largely disappeared, and there are now just a few places where the original play of the Star boys can be counted as an unbroken linear tradition, for instance the islands Amager in Denmark, and Haram and Vigra on the west coast of Norway, but the most famous one is probably the Star boys' singing procession in the small town of Grimstad on the south coast of Norway.<ref>The Grimstad custom is encouraged by local people of influence – journalists, teachers and local historians – who train the new boys and maintain standards. However, the grown ups also prevent changes in the tradition.</ref>{{Citation needed|date=January 2018}}
=== Sweden === In 19th century the Swedish Star boys started to join in with horse riding on St. Stephen's Day, 26 December. The tradition of Star boys (sometimes even with [[Judas Iscariot]]), singing and acting about [[Christmas]], [[Saint Stephen and Herod|Saint Stephen]] and [[Epiphany (holiday)|Epiphany]], has traditionally been performed from St. Stephen's Day until Epiphany.
Today they are only to be seen bringing up the rear together with bridesmaids and elves as a part of the [[Saint Lucy's Day|Lucia]] procession on December 13. Recently school teachers, nursery nurses and Christian clergymen have tried to revitalize the play for small children, inviting their parents to come to the schools, the kindergartens or the churches to see it performed. But the popular and more humorous folkloristic elements of the play are often left out.
=== Finland === In Finland, a version of the Star boys' procession originating in the city of [[Oulu]], a musical play known as ''Tiernapojat'', has become established as a cherished Christmas tradition nationwide. The ''Tiernapojat'' show is a staple of Christmas festivities in schools, kindergartens, and elsewhere, and it is broadcast every Christmas on radio and television. The Finnish version contains non-biblical elements such as king Herod vanquishing the "king of the Moors", and a short song of praise to [[Alexander II of Russia|Tsar Alexander]].
== Star singer songs == * ''Die heil′gen drei König′ mit ihrigem Stern, ''text and melody from Bavaria (18th century). * ''Die Legende von den drei weisen Königen'', text: Rolf Krenzer, melody: [[Ludger Stühlmeyer]] ([[ZDF]]-Star singer event 1999). * ''Die Weisen aus dem Morgenland'', text and melodie: Kurt Rommel. * ''Drei Könige führte Gottes Hand'', text: [[Friedrich Spee]], melody: Cologn, 1880. * ''Erfüll mit deinen Gnaden Herr Jesus dieses Haus'' (Ein Kind ist uns geboren), Leipzig 1884. * ''[[Es ist für uns eine Zeit angekommen]]'', text and melody from Swissland (19th century). * ''Es ziehn aus weiter Ferne drei Könige einher'', text and melody from Austria. * ''Gott griaß enk Laidln ollesombt, megn sai so fü enk woin'', from Bavaria. * ''Heller Stern in der dunklen Nacht'', text: [[Diethard Zils]], melody: France 1874 ''([[Il est né le divin enfant]])''. * ''Hier kommen die Könige, sie folgen einem Stern'', text: Rolf Krenzer, melody [[Peter Janssens]]. * ''Nun sehet den Stern, den wir bringen'', text: [[Georg Thurmair]], melody: [[Adolf Lohmann]]. * ''Seht den Stern, den wir euch bringen'', text: Peter Gerloff, melody: Ludger Stühlmeyer, 2016.<ref>Maria Palmer, ''Wegweiser wahrnehmen. Das Dreikönigslied „Seht den Stern, den wir euch bringen“ von Peter Gerloff und Ludger Stühlmeyer''. In: ''Heinrichsblatt, Katholische Wochenzeitung des Erzbistums Bamberg'', Heinrichs-Verlag Bamberg, No. 1, January 1, 2017, (p. 13).</ref><ref>In: ''Karfunkel ABC der Weihnachtsbräuche''. Ruth Franke: ''Weise, Magier, Astronomen. Die hl. drei Könige''. December 2018 p. 30–34, {{ISBN|978-3-935616-72-0}}.</ref> * ''Seht ihr unsern Stern dort stehen'', text: Zils, melody: France 18. Jahrhundert ''(Les Anges dans nos campagnes)''.<ref>In: [[Gotteslob]], No. 262, Katholische Bibelanstalt Stuttgart 2013.</ref> * ''[[Stern über Bethlehem]], zeig uns den Weg'', text and melody: [[Alfred Hans Zoller]], 1964. * ''Wir heil'gen drei Könige mit unserm Stern'', Folksong. * ''Wir kommen daher aus dem Morgenland'', text: Maria Ferschl, melody: Heinrich Rohr. * ''Wir sind die drei Könige'', text and music: Kurt Mikula.
== See also == * [[Cavalcade of Magi]] * [[Chalking the door]] (Scotland) * [[King Cake]] * [[:pl:Kolęda (wizyta duszpasterska)|kolęda]] (Poland) * [[Liturgical drama]] * [[Medieval theatre]] * [[Mystery play]] * [[Rosca de reyes]] * [[:cs:Tříkrálová sbírka]] (Czech Republic)
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
=== Bibliography === * Manfred Becker-Huberti: ''Die Heiligen Drei Könige. Geschichten, Legenden und Bräuche''. Greven Verlag, Köln. {{ISBN|3-7743-0356-8}}. * Carsten Bregenhøj: ''Helligtrekongersløb på Agersø: Socialt, statistik og strukturelt''. Dansk Folkemindesamling, Skrifter 3. Copenhagen 1974. * Laurits Bødker: ''Folk Literature (Germanic)''. International Dictionary of Regional European Ethnology and Folklore Volume II. Rosenkilde and Bagger. Copenhagen 1965. * Hilding Celander: ''Stjärngossarna. Deres visor och julspel''. Nordiska museets Handlingar:38. Stockholm 1950. * Frederick J. Marker & Lise-Lone Marker: ''A history of Scandinavian theatre''. Cambridge University Press. Cambridge 1996. * [[Erik Henning Edvardsen]] 1993, see Hans Wiers-Jenssen & Haakon Hougen. * Terry Gunnell: ''The Origins of Drama in Scandinavia''. D.S. Brewer, Woodbridge 1994 (1995). * B. Hayward (1992) ''Galoshins: The Scottish Folk Play''. Edinburgh University Press, Edinburgh 1992. {{ISBN|0-7486-0338-7}} * [[Reidar Kjellberg]]: Helligtrekonger (p. 205-210). ''At gavne og fornøie. Et utvalg av hans arbeider ved Gordon Hølmebakk''. Gyldendal Norsk Forlag, Oslo 1984. * [[John Paulsen]]: En gammeldags julaften. ''Juleaften''. Aktieselsk. Biglers Forlag. Kristiania [1897]. * [[Iørn Piø]]: ''Bogen om julen. Historien om julen og dens traditioner''. Sesam. Copenhagen 1998. {{ISBN|978-87-7258-570-3}} * [[Klara Semb]]: Julestjerna. ''For Bygd og By'' nr. 25-26. Julenummer 1925. * [[Kathleen Stokker]]: ''Keeping Christmas. Yuletide Traditions in Norway and the New Land''. Minnesota Historical Society Press. MS 2000. {{ISBN|0-87351-390-8}}. * [[Hans Wiers-Jenssen]] & Haakon Hougen: ''Stjernespill og stjernesang i Norge. "Norvegia Sacra" 1921 og 1937''. [Reprint of earlier periodical articles and an updated investigation of later oral and written sources to the star play, the singing procession and the star boy tradition in Norway and a short description of the custom elsewhere in the world, by Erik Henning Edvardsen, p. V-VII and p. 109- 160.] Norsk Folkeminnelags skrifter nr. 138 / [[Norsk Folkeminnelag]]. Oslo 1993. {{ISBN|82-991811-2-7}}.
== External links == * [http://www.sternsinger.org Website about charities that are helped by Star singers in Germany] (in German) * [http://www.dka.at The Three Wise Men in the Catholic Youth Organization in Austria] (in German) * [http://www.oulu.ouka.fi/ppm/tilapaisnayttely/vanhat_nayttelyt/tiernapojat1.htm Historic, Finnish sourches from North Österbotten (Pohjois-Pohjanmaan) Museum] (in Finnish) * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110605130750/http://www.kotus.fi/index.phtml?s=1087 Taru Kolehmainen: Julesanger (Joululaulujen)] – the expression of tradition (in Finnish) * [https://archive.is/20121209134043/http://verkkokirjasto.ouka.fi/oulunarkki/arkki_kaunokirjallisuus.aspx?teema=24&nimi=Joulu&valikko=23 Preparation for the star play in Oulun] (in Finnish) * [http://www.tiernapojat.net/ Star Boys in Helsinki Finland] (in Finnish)

page.title: Stephen Fry's Incomplete and Utter History of Classical Music

revision.comment: Replace [[Help:Magic links|magic links]] with templates per [[Special:Permalink/772743896#Future of magic links|local RfC]] and [[:mw:Requests for comment/Future of magic links|MediaWiki RfC]]
revision.text:
{{italic title}} '''''Stephen Fry's Incomplete and Utter History of Classical Music''''' is a book [[ghostwriter|ghostwritten]] by Tim Lihoreau for author, actor, comedian and director [[Stephen Fry]].Copyright identification, 2005 edition It is based on Fry's regular [[Classic FM (UK)]] radio slot and is a book about the history of [[classical music]]. Fellow radio host Lihoreau has written a range of Classic FM publications along similar lines. Fry provided a Foreword in which he states that it is "a very personal book" (p. ix). Although the book is written in the [[First-person narrative|first person]], the nature and extent of Fry's contribution is not otherwise explained. ==References== Hardback published by Boxtree (2004) ({{ISBN|0-7522-2534-0}})
Paperback published by Pan (2005) ({{ISBN|0-330-43856-5}}) {{Stephen Fry}} [[Category:2004 books]] [[Category:Books by Stephen Fry]] [[Category:Music books]] {{music-publication-stub}}
